Brockbank and Co., of Cowper's-court, Cornhill, and found it was never made by them, and afterwards to Mr. Carter, the rater, and found it never was rated by him.

Cross-examined by MR. WOLLETT. Q. How long have you been in Mr. Barker's service? A. Seven years; he is in a large way of business—we have a number of watches in the course of the year and several chronometers, but not a great many—I believe the people in our shop are considered to be very experienced—12l. is not a small sum to advance, taking it to be a valuable chronometer—it is not a saleable thing every day—we have sold chrono
meters at a sale for 12l., and we have one now we can sell for 10l. 10s.—Brockbank's name is on this—our manager looked at it—perhaps the exami
nation

lasted a quarter of an hour—we had no opportunity of making inquiry about it—we inspected it, and came to the conclusion that we could lend 12l. on it—we are not practical men—it was after a very careful exami
nation—we always look at a thing before we buy it or lend money on it—I will not give any opinion, as to whether I am very anxious to convict in this case—we have had the watch examined, and the watchmaker says the movements are not worth 10s., it is silver—I objected to lend 5l. on it—I do not call all silver watches duffers—they are obliged to put duffing works into silver cases to make them appear gennine—this case is not particularly strong for a chronometer, it would be worth about 2l. as a chronometer—the prisoner did not say Anns was the person's name he got the chronometer from—he gave his own name as William Anns—he wrote that—he said nothing—I afterwards went to the address and found William Anns there, who I have known three years—I do not know whether the prisoner gave that to mean his own name or the man from whom he got it—no one asked him who he got the chronometer from.
MR. CLAKKSON. Q. You looked at it with such judgment as you had? A. Yes; we never had one under such circumstances before.

SAMUEL ELLIOTT ATKINS . I belong to the firm of Atkins and Son, late Brockbank's, of Cowper's-court, Cornhill—this chronometer has "Brockbank, Cornhill, London," and "Brockbank, Cowper's-court, Cornhill, No. 462" on it—it was never made in our house, we never sent it to Mr. Carter—I should be very sorry to give 80s. for it—with the exception of the box and the materials of which it is composed, it is worth nothing at all—as a chro
nometer it is perfectly useless—if I had it I should not know what to do with it—this index denotes the number of days it goes without wind
ing—upon winding it up this hand should return to the word "up," which indicates that it is fully wound up, and it would return back day by day as it ran down—there should be a wheel within, in connection with the index to operate upon it—there is a wheel inside, but it has no connection at all with the index; it is placed there for imposition more than anything, it has no connection with any part of the work—when it was left with me the hand was at the word "wind," as if it had gone down seven days—I wound it up, and the hand remained where it was—I took it out of the case, and found that it was not connected with the wheels—it went four or five hours, and lost between forty and forty-five minutes—in my judgment it was made to deceive, it has no chronometical properties about it—the dial is similar to ours—I have looked at the watch, it is something of the same character—there is no other firm of Brockbank and Co.

Cross-examined. Q. How many persons have you in your establishment? A. Five; we are not frequently changing hands—I have been there twenty years and there has been only one change, that was seven years ago, and that man discharged himself—I cannot swear none of our workmen made this chro
nometer—I have frequently seen watches with our name on them which have not been our make—it never happened to us that our workmen made watches with the firm's name on them—the watch has a pretty strong silver case, the name of Stafford is on it—I never saw or heard of him—I should call it a very vile imitation of a chronometer—it is valueless to me—I should be very sorry to give 5l. for it—I should say it would be an extrava
gant price—it is difficult for me to say what it is worth, it is totally out of my way.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Of course these duffing articles would find no circula
tion unless the outside case was silver? A. No.

JOHN CARTER . I am a chronometer-maker oft' Cornhill, and am in the habit of rating chronometers—I have had great experience in it—my atten
tion has been called to this chronometer, and the card in the box—it is one of my cards, I do not know how it got into the box—I never rated it—it is valueless, and utterly incapable of being rated—that which pretends to be an index is altogether fraudulent.
MR. WOOLLETT to HENRY BILLSON. Q. You saw Anns? A. Yes; he didnot say it was his chronometer; he said, "I suppose you want your money back?—it was left for me, we must settle it."

MR. CLARKSON. Q. If Anns had come himself, he would not have succeeded in getting any money? A. No; I had known him ten years—I knocked at the door, and one of the daughters, I believe, opened it—I saw Anns, and he said, "Oh, what the devil are you up to in stopping that watch?"—I said, "I have come to say nothing about any watch, I have merely come to ask you a question"—he said, "Come in," and said, "I suppose you want your money back for the chronometer that was left for me? I sup
pose we had better settle it? are you going to have me to-night"—I said, "I have come to say nothing about it at all; I have merely come to ask you a question, when you allow me to do so"—he said, "Sit down, what will you have, wine or brandy, or what?"—I said, "No, thank you"—he went on a lot about it, and said, "As to that chap Galley, I will stick to him tooth and nail if it cost me 100,000l."—I said, I had merely come to ask him a question.

WILLIAM ENGLAND BARREN . I am assistant to Messrs. Barker, at the Aldgate shop. About three o'clock one day in Aug., a man came to our shop
be came again two hours after with Anns, and I believe he produced the same chronometer in a handkerchief—I said, "Anns, I am glad to see you come with that man, for he has been before with a chronometer, and seeing you with with him I know it is not a genuine article"—Anns said, "Oh, never mind, I have stuck one into your other house with old Tom for 12l."
Cross-examined. Q. You do not know the other man? A. No; I should know him if I saw him.

GUILTY .** Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.

138.
JOHN BAILEY
, unlawfully obtaining goods by false pretences, from
James Cousins. MR. BALLANTINE conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES COUSINS . I am a currier of 2, Luke-street, Shoreditch. On 18th May, the prisoner came and chose some leather which came to 25l. 16s. or there
abouts—I was to be paid by a bill on Mrs. Allford, his mother-in-law, who he said was a widow woman of fortune, and the rest in cash—on that I sent the goods—if I bad supposed Mrs. Allford had been a married woman, I should not have parted with the goods—I received this bill for 20l., dated 28th May, at three months (produced)—at maturity it was presented to Mrs. Allford—it was not paid, and I then found out she was not a widow—I have never got the money or the skins back—I applied to the prisoner for it, and in one instance he said he hoped I might get it—I cannot say how long it was after it had become due—I had received several promises—I told him I would go and see Mrs. Allford, somebody must pay it—he said, "I wish you may get it," and put his hand up to his nose.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL Q. Had you been having a dispute with him when he put his hand to his nose? A. Call it a dispute if you like; it was as jou ask a debtor for money—the conversation bad been quiet

till I found myself defrauded—I had told him I thought the bill ought to be paid—I do not reeollect the words I used; you may guess I was not very well pleased—I dare say I had been angry—I had known him since before last Christmas, and had had dealings with him to 6l. or 7l. at various times—that was when he was in business in Luke-street—he did not consult me about taking a larger place in Holy well-lane—he told me he was going to move his business—I did not upon that advise him to increase his stock—I did not tell him I should be very willing to supply him if he wanted a larger stock—I wished he might do better than he had done in Luke-street—I bad not complained that he had not had much of me while he was in Luke-street—I did not tell him he had better have some skins I had got nearly finished to stock his new shop with; I am quite sure of that—these goods were to stock his shop, or do what he pleased with it if I got my money—he paid me a part of the balance of cash about two months after—I never had any acceptance of his before—I have seen two other acceptances supposed to be Mrs. Allford's—I do not know whether they were paid—I applied to Mrs. Allford about this bill: she did not ask for time—I did not, before I let him have the goods, go and ask Mrs. Allford if it was her acceptance—I did make inquiry, but not of her personally—I was satisfied with the inquiry or I should not have let him have the goods—I have seen Mrs. Allford since, and shown her the bill—she did not admit it was her writing, she seemed rather to doubt it—I have not stated repeatedly that I have ascertained it to be her writing—I have not told her husband so—I feel satisfied it is Bailey's writing—I swear, I have not over and over again said I believed it was Mrs. Allford's writing—I cannot positively recollect, but I feel satisfied in my own mind that I stated quite the other way—I do not know that the body of it is Bailey's writing—I do not know who wrote the bill—I said just now I had no doubt in my own mind of the acceptance being the prisoner's writing, because I saw him endorse it, and it was very much like the acceptance—I have been four, five, six, or seven years in business—I found out after the bill became due, that Mrs. Allford was living with Mr. Allford, at Dalston—I had previously made inquiry to ascertain that there was a Mrs. Allford, and that she was possessed of considerable property—I swear the prisoner did not give me her address on a piece of paper—I have no recollection of it—I made inquiries of a customer of mine, and I made inquiry at a house in Dalston, and ascertained she was living at Dalston—he bad told roe she lived at Dalston—I think I can swear he did not give me the address on paper.

MR. BALLANTINE Q. Did you ascertain that she was a married woman, and not a widow, before you parted with your goods? A. I only asked in a baker's shop if there was a Mrs. Allford living there, and they said there was—I believed her to be a widow—I have never seen her write—I have seen a bill or two which I was told were her writing—I cannot say whether this acceptance is hers or not.

JOHN ALLFORD . I am the husband of the lady whose name has been mentioned—she is not a woman of fortune—I am a builder—the prisoner married Mrs. Allford's youngest daughter by a former marriage—I married Mrs. Allford nearly ten years ago, and live with her now—she is now at Dalston—I cannot give you any reason why she is not here—I consider the word "accepted" on this bill is her writing, "payable at Holywell-lane" is not—she had no authority from me to accept bills—I have no doubt the prisoner knew she was married.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you refuse to allow her to come here? A. No; she did not ask my permission to come—she has been advised by the family not to come—I lived with her six or seven years before I married her—she was then Mrs. Hull—she received between 60l. and 70l. under her late father's will in Yorkshire, on the winding up of the concern, five or six years ago—it did not pass through my hands—I only know that, from what she told me—we were married at the time, but she had the control of it—our marriage was not kept secret; many parts of the family knew it, and many parts not—we lived five or six years without being married—the family knew that we were married only by our telling them—none of the family were present only ourselves, the clergyman, and the clerk, who gave her away by her wish—the family knew of it the day after—I had not heard remarks before about our being married or not married—they always supposed we were married—I do not know how many weeks after, or how long after Mr. Hall's death it was that I began living with her—I am not aware that it was before his death—I have seen a great many other acceptances of hers—they have not been paid to my knowledge—I know there are several not paid—I cannot say whether there are several paid—the prisoner was not a favourite of hers that I am aware of—he saw her very frequently, and against my wishes—I did not approve of his coming to my house—I never had any money from my wife—we now live at 6, Holley-street, North Dalston—we have lived there two years and a half, and in the neighbourhood eight years—we did live in Bath-place, Dalston, and gave that up last Michaelmas two years—I paid the rent for that house—application was not made for the rates of that house in the name of Hull—I never paid them in that name.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You have paid them? A. Yes; I do not know of my own knowledge that there are any acceptances of Mrs. Allford's that have been paid—I know there are some not paid.
GEORGE NICHOLSON . I am a currier and leather-seller. I know the prisoner—I have had conversations with him about his mother-in-law—he and his wife always represented that she was married.
Cross-examined. Q. They always called him Mr. Allford and her Mrs. Allford? A. Yes, that is what I mean.

JOHN SMITH . I keep a beer-shop, 1, Chapel-street, Curtain-road—the prisoner gave me some bills to get cashed—we went to a friend of mine, and I had some conversation with the prisoner as to whether Mrs. Allford was single or married—the bills were not cashed, and the prisoner took them away—after that transaction, at the beginning of May, the prisoner told me Mrs. Allford was married, but had plenty of property in Yorkshire, and would pay these bills.

Cross-examined. Q. Does the prisoner hold any acceptance of yours which you have not paid? A. Yes, one for 40l., which he ought not to have—he has not got two 30l. bills besides—I was before the Magistrate, but did not give evidence—I have known the prisoner about seventeen months—all the dealings I have had with him were lending and borrowing.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you borrowed money of him? A. No, not a halfpenny—I have lent him 2l. or 3l. at times—he came to me, and could not pay a bill of 30l. against him—he said a friend of his would cash it if I would give my acceptance, and I gave it him—he did not get it cashed, but gave it to a person named Best.
MR. PARNELL. Q. Has he not been in the habit of lending you 6l. a week, to pay your brewer? A. Never, not 1l.—I have gone and asked him
for money owing to me when I wanted to pay it, and sometimes I have got 1l. when he has owed me 2l. or 3l., and sometimes got none.

SUSAN TAYLOR . I am Mrs. Allford's eldest daughter—my husband is a comedian; the prisoner is my brother-in-law—I have known him from a child—he has borne the very best of characters; he was just starting this new shop.
JURY. Q. Did you know of the marriage? A. No.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Where does your husband play? A. The last letter I had from him was from Dundee, and he is now at Glasgow—he left me twelve weeks ago—I was not present at my mother's second marriage; I was abroad, and when I came home I heard she was married—I cannot say now who told me; she did not—the prisoner married my sister nearly four years ago, since my mother's marriage—I did tell Mr. Cousins that my mother had been married years ago—I did not tell him I had no doubt about it.

MR. PARNELL. Q. You say you heard it; did you believe it? A, I doubted it, as my mother had lived so many years with him—I have been home three years next March—it was some time after I came home that I heard it—I did not know who Cousins was when he inquired of me—when I came home he was standing at the gate, and asked for Mr. Bailey, saying, "I have been to your mother's, and find he is here"—he said Mr. Bailey told him he could find him at his mother's—I said he had better go there—he said, "I know where Mr. Bailey lives;" and I said then he had no occasion to come there to find him—he then said, "Mrs. Allford has a son by the present husband," and then, "Mrs. Allford is married?"—I said, "Yes, she is mar
ried"—I did not believe the report when I heard it—it was not generally believed in the family. (Several other witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Six Months.

139.
WILLIAM HIBBERD
, unlawfully assaulting
Hannah Maria Johns, with intent, &c.
GUILTY
of an Assault.—
Confined Six Months.

140.
CHARLES JAMES SMITH
, unlawfully attempting to commit b—st—y.
NOT GUILTY .

141.
CHARLES LEIGHTON and
CHARLOTTE LEIGHTON were indicted
(with William Keen, not in custody) for obtaining goods by false pretences. MR. CARTER conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE DIXON . I am clerk to John Henry Macber, who is proprietor of 43, Wynyatt-street, Goswell-road, which was to let. The prisoners came to my master's office on 12tb or 18th July, and applied for the house—the female had been before, and represented her name as Steed, and when she came on 12th or 13th she introduced the male prisoner as her husband, saying, "This is Mr. Steed"—he said he had been employed a number of years in the Ordnance Department at Woolwich, and the person who placed him there had given him a superior situation at Somerset House—I said I should require the usual references, and he referred me to Daniel Good, the landlord of his house, at Woolwich, and gave me his address—I found him at the address, and considered his representations satisfactory—he also referred me to Mr. Boudler, of Jewin-crescent—in consequence of those references, I let him the house, and he entered into this agreement (produced)—I saw him sign it,

"Arthur Steed," and witnessed it myself—he went into possession of the house—I saw the female prisoner there in Aug.—early in Oct. I received a parcel by the Parcels' Delivery Company, containing the key of the house, and this letter, which, from my knowledge of the male prisoner's writing, I believe to be his—(read)—"3d Oct., 1849. Sir,—From unforseen circum
stances, I have been compelled to resign my situation, and of course I am not in circumstances to continue your tenant; I therefore forward you the key, and will call on you in a few days with a view to the settlement of the rent due. A. STEED.")—he did not call—I never saw him again till he was in custody.
Cross-examined by MR. DAWSON. Q. How many rooms are there in the house? A, Eight; the rent was 32l.—the house next door is mine—I believe the houses in the street are let out in lodgings.

CALEB TIBBETTS . I live at 10, Great Ormond-street, and am proprietor of 11, Remington-street, City-road. The female prisoner came to me about 27th Sept., and wished to look at that house, and appointed for me to meet her husband there at four o'clock that afternoon—I went, met both the pri
soners, and they agreed to take the house—I asked the male prisoner for his reference—he gave me his name as Blessington; said he had been in the Excise at Woolwich, and was removed to Broad-street, and gave me the name, "Steed, 13, Wynyatt-street," as a reference, who, he said, was the landlord of the house he occupied at Woolwich—the male prisoner accompanied me to the door of that house—I saw a person there who represented himself as Mr. Steed, and his statements seemed satisfactory—we then returned to the house, where the female still was, and I let it to them, and gave them the key—the rent was 28l.—I happened to pass the house in Wynyatt-street two or three days after, in the beginning of Oct., and saw it shut up, and the windows plas
tered over with mud—my suspicions were then aroused—I found the whole statement false, and I left a message to that effect at my house, and wished them to leave it immediately—a man calling himself Keen, who said he lived in Smith-street, called on me directly after, said he worked for Mr. Blessing
ton, and he considered they were very respectable parties—I said I was not satisfied, and wished them to quit it—the possession was given up to me three or four days ago, since the prisoners have been in custody.

THOMAS WEBBER RICHARDS . I am a linen-draper, in the Goswell-road. About the end of Oct. the female prisoner, and a man she represented to be her husband, not the male prisoner, came to my shop—they stated that their name was Keen, and they lived at 5, Upper Smith-street, Northampton-square—they said an uncle of theirs had died, they wanted a little mourning, and wished credit for a short time—that he had left them 200l. or 300l. which was likely to be paid in five or six weeks—I required a reference, and they referred me to Mr. Leighton, of Remington-street, a builder—I agreed to call on him, and they were to call on me to know the result—I called that day or the day after, and saw Leighton, it was the male prisoner—I said, "You are Mr. Leighton, the builder?"—he said, "Yes"—I then asked if he knew Mr. Keen, of 5, Upper Smith-street, he said he did—I said they wanted goods on credit, and asked if he would give them a character—he said he would give them an excellent character; they had lost a friend, and he had lent them money—he gave me to understand they were husband and wife—I asked him how long he had resided at that house, he said, some consider
able time—I think he told me twelve months—I told him, in consequence of the character I had no objection to give credit; and he said it would be all right, it was quite safe—the parties came again that evening, and

asked if I had been to see Mr. Leighton, I told them I had—they asked if I was satisfied, and I said I should have no objection to let them have the goods—the female said she hoped it would be settled in six weeks, and wished to look out the goods—I said it was late, and wished it to be postponed till the Monday—the female came on the Monday, and began selecting some twill merinos and other things, to the amount of 7l. or 8l.—while she was selecting them, I called her away from the counter, and said, "You are Mrs. Keen?"—she said she was—I told her I did not like to go much above 5l.; and she said I need not frighten myself, that her husband was a respect
able working man, and it was all right—she said her husband worked for Mr. Leighton—the goods were afterwards sent to the place she asked—she came again in two or three days for some more goods—I called her into the parlour, and told her the bill was between 7l. and 8l—she said, oh, she had done nothing but what her husband knew of—a short time after, I re
ceived this letter (produced)—I sent for Keen—he came to the shop, and I asked him questions out of the letter—I asked him if his cousin was a respectable man, as he wanted to have goods on credit—he said it would be quite safe to let him have the goods, he was a very respectable hard-working man, and lived in Shoreditch—in consequence of suspicion, I afterwards made inquiry at Smith-street, and saw only the servant—I went to Remington-street, and could not get admission—on Saturday evening, 10th Nov., I went again to Remington-street with a policeman—after a time we got admission, and there found the two prisoners—I said to the female, "You are the woman I want, as Mrs. Keen"—she said," This is my husband; he did not give you a false reference"—the male prisoner was at her side—I looked at the male, and recognised him as the man who had given me the character—I gave them both in charge—the male prisoner cried, and on going to the station, the female said, "I never had any goods of you—they both gave the name of Leighton at the station—on the Monday evening I went with the policeman and the two prisoners again to Remington-street, and on the way the female said, "I declare to God I have not got the goods; I gave them to Keen; if I was let go I could produce them easily"—when she first came to the shop she was very respectably dressed, better than afterwards.

Q. The female made the bargain? A. Yes; nothing was said about paying by instalments—it was on the consideration that I was to have the money in six weeks, and the reference, that I let her have the goods—I was not astonished at the order she gave—she was respectably dressed—Saturday evening is a busy time—the shop is 200 or 300 yards from Wynyatt-street—I never saw Keen with the male prisoner.

EDWIN HICKOX . I am shopman to Mr. Richards—I recollect the female prisoner coming there on Monday, 29th Oct.—I served her with fourteen yards of merino, twenty-one of Coburg cloth, four shawls, six pairs of hose, two handkerchiefs, some crape-silk lining, and two umbrellas'; mostly mourning goods—she directed them to be sent to No. 5, Upper Smith-street, in the name of Keen—I sent them by the shop-boy—she came again on 2d Nov., when Mr. Richards was out, and said she had also lost her aunt—it was in the cholera time—she came again a third time, and selected a small parcel, which I sent, addressed in the same manner—she asked for the bill, and I gave it her.

JOHN RICHARD CHALLERTON . I am in Mr. Richards's service—I took a parcel directed, "Mr. Keen, 5, Upper Smith-street, Northampton-square," to that house—I saw the female prisoner—I asked if Mr. Keen lived there,

she said it was all right—I left the parcel with her—two or three days after I took another parcel to the same house, addressed, "Mrs. Keen"—a ser
vant opened the door, and Mrs. Keen was in the passage—I left a third parcel on the following day.

WILLIAM HENRY BANKS . I carry on business at 50, King-street, New North-road—I have known the male prisoner fourteen or fifteen months—I always believed his name to be Joseph Gummer—I always understood he was a clerk in the Bank of England—he owes me money now—I believe he is married—I think the female prisoner is not his wife—I never heard of his carrying on the business of a builder.
Cross-examined. Q. Is all that you can say against him, that he owes you money? A. Yes; he was then in a very respectable condition of life.

JOHN HARVEY (policeman). On Saturday, 10th November, at eight o'clock in the evening, I went with Mr. Richards to 11, Remington-street—the male prisoner opened the door—he tried to force me out again, but I got in, and Mr. Richards followed—the two prisoners were in the house—Mr. Richards charged them with obtaining goods under false pretences from him—they said Mr. Richards was mistaken; they had never been to his shop, and did not know where he lived—on the Monday evening we went with the prosecutor and searched the house—we found nothing; and on return
ing again, the male prisoner said, "If Mr. Richards had not been so fast, be would have seen Keen, and very likely the goods would have been returned."

JOEL HILL (policeman A 441). I assisted in apprehending the prisoners on the Saturday—the female said Mr. Richards was mistaken, she had never been in the shop in her life—on the Monday, on the way from the Court, she said, "I had the goods, and what of it;" if he was fool enough to get rid of his things it was nothing to her—on the way back from Remington-street, she said, if Mr. Richards had not been so fast, she would have caused Keen to have been apprehended, and the goods restored—I cautioned her, and told her what she explained to me I should tell the Magistrate.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you been on the look out for Keen? A. Yes; I have not been able to find him.

CHARLES LEIGHTON—
GUILTY .* Aged 44.

CHARLOTTE LEIGHTON—
GUILTY .* † Aged 42.

142.
WALTER ROGERS and
JOHN HOGAN
, stealing 1 till, 4 shillings, 4 half-crowns, 12 shillings, 2 sixpences, 2 groats, 6 pence, 72 halfpence, and 159 farthings; the property of
Thomas Bullock: to which

HOGAN pleaded
GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

SARAH BULLOCK . I am the daughter of Thomas Bullock, of Stratford. The till produced is his property—I saw it safe on 28th Nov., about twenty minutes to eleven o'clock in the morning—there was about 1l.-worth of silver, and 10s.-worth of copper in it, in half-crowns, shillings, sixpences, and 4d.-pieces—I missed it a few minutes after—the prisoner Hogan was near the window from ten to a quarter to eleven, and Rogers was on the opposite side.

RICHARD ROGERS . I am in Mr. Bullock's service; Rogers is my brother. On 28th Nov., in consequence of what was said to me, I went from the shop, and about two hundred yards off I found the till by the side of a tree, near

the footpath—I made inquiry of a gentleman I met, went on, and overtook the prisoners—I said, "You have been at a fine thing"—they said they would give me the money if I would let them go—they both gave me some money, and I took them back to the shop.

JOHN SMITH . I am in Mr. Bullock's service. I went with the last witness, and found the till where he says—we went on, overtook the prisoners, and I said, "Now, then, we know you have got that money; you had better give it up; what fools you must be to take that till"—they gave up the money—we took them both back to the shop, and I gave the money to Miss Bullock—I had seen them before, that day; one against the shop-window, and the other on the opposite side of the way.

ROGERS—
GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

143.
SARAH ANN MILLER
, stealing 1 guard-chain, value 6l. 6s.; the goods of
William Postlethwaite, in the dwelling-house of
Louisa Hagg.

FREDERICK ALEXANDER . I am a surgeon, of Stratford. I knew the prisoner in the service of Miss Hagg, where the prosecutor, Mr. William Postlethwaite, resides—I know that he lost his guard-chain—I heard that the prisoner was seen with one; I communicated it to him, and he requested me to see after it—I waited on the prisoner two days afterwards, at the residence of her uncle—I asked her for the guard-chain—she denied it at first, hut afterwards she said she had parted with the chain—I said, "You will have no objection to tell me where you parted with it?"—she said to a young man—she went up-stairs to her uncle, and he brought down the duplicate—I took it home to Mr. Postlethwaite; he is not here; he is ill, and not able to-attend—I have this certificate from another surgeon—this is Mr. Postlethwaite's chain; he identified it, and gave his deposition—I saw him this morning, and it is impossible for him to come here—(the deposition teas here read—" William Postlethwaite, on his oath, saith: 'I reside at 3, High-street, Stratford. I am lodging with Miss Hagg. The prisoner was servant in the house. On the 4th inst. I missed a gold watch-chain from a drawer in my bed-room; I had seen it a week before; this is it. I never gave the prisoner the chain, or any authority to pawn it.")
THOMAS RAWLINSON . I saw the prisoner with this chain round her neck—I asked her how she came by it—she told me her brother gave it her, who is gone to sea.
JOSEPH MOLES (policeman, K 327). I took the prisoner—she told me that Mr. Postlethwaite gave her the chain for having connexion with her.

FREDERICK ALEXANDER
re-examined. Q. What is the nature of Mr. Postlethwaite's illness? A. Paralysis; he has had several attacks—his mind is affected to some extent—I think he would not have given her the chain—his irritation of brain has made him excitable, but be knows the value of property, and would know when he lost anything.
NOT GUILTY .

144.
SARAH ANN MILLER was again indicted
for stealing 1 ring, value 5s.; the goods of
Louisa Hagg, her mistress.

LOUISA HAGG . I am single. I reside at 3, High-street, Stratford—the prisoner was in my service—I lost a ring, and had asked her repeatedly about it, when I had missed other articles—I said I had lost it from the mantel
piece, and she must have known about it—this is my ring (produced).
JANE Low. The prisoner is my daughter. I have been married again—she gave me this ring.
Prisoner. I picked it up in sweeping, and gave it to my mother.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

145.
JOHN HARRIS and
GEORGE BROWN
, stealing 2 iron plough-shares, and other articles, value 1s. 4d.; the goods of
William Adams.

JOSEPH MILTON . I am bailiff to Mr. William Adams. I found the prisoners breaking up some rails on 23d Nov., about twenty yards from my master's; I took them back to my master's yard—they had a bag between them—I found in it some iron hoops, which had been broken up—these plough-shares and rails are all my master's; I challenged the prisoners; they said they found them in a ditch.

JAMES BONE . I am in the employ of Mr. Adams. About four o'clock, on 23d Nov., I saw Harris go into the yard, and go to the cart-shed—when he came back he had this iron in his hand, and he took it out; Brown was about twenty yards from him—when Harris took the iron out Brown jumped upon it, and broke it.
Harris. He has only just come out of Guildford gaol, for stealing apples; he had one month. Witness. I have been there.
Brown's Defence. I was not near the premises; the things were of no use to any one.
(Brown received a good character.)

HARRIS—
GUILTY . Aged 38.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

146.
FRANCIS THOMPSON
, stealing 8 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 3 pence; the moneys of
John William Ford, from his person.

JOHN WILLIAM FORD . I am a tobacco-pipe manufacturer. On 27th NOV. I was in the Shakspere's Head, Stratford—I got drunk, and got dancing with a man—I had in my left pocket 9s. 6d. in silver, and 3d. in halfpence—I lost 8s. 6d. and 3d.; I cannot tell how.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINB. Q. You were tipsy when this money was lost? A. Yes, but I was not without other money—my lad brought me 3s.; to the door, from some customer in Chapel-street.
JOHN STACEY . I was in this beer-shop—I saw them dancing—I saw the prisoner put his hand into my master's, Mr. Ford's, left-hand pocket—I did not see any money come out.
Cross-examined. Q. What, was your master drunk? A. Yes; he was dancing with the prisoner, and two or three more men—they were not dancing, they were jumping round the room; they were not all drunk.
NOT GUILTY .

147.
WILLIAM WALTERS
, stealing 3 pairs of gloves, 1 handkerchief, and 1 measure, value 10s.; the goods of
Henry Parry.

HENRY PARRY . I am a solicitor, and live at Florence-terrace, Deptford, On the morning of 7th Nov., between one and two o'clock, I was at the White Horse, Greenwich, and placed a great-coat on a chair in the coffee-room, in which there were three pairs of gloves, a pocket-handkerchief, some loose papers, and a six-feet tape measure—I missed the coat, and on inquiring for it was told by the landlord I had come into the house without one—I said

I had not, and insisted on its being found—the landlord afterwards brought it me, and told me he had taken it from the tap-room, some one had removed it from the parlour—I lost my things—on leaving the house I saw the prisoner, with some others, in front of the bar—he came behind me, and threw some flour over me—I turned round, and saw him, called for a police
man, and gave him into custody for assaulting me, and on being searched at the station my gloves, handkerchief, and the measure were found in his pocket—these produced are them.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Were you not very drunk? A. No, perfectly sober—I usually take my coat off when I go into a house—I did not take my other coat off as well—I did not take off my great-coat for the purpose of fighting; I had no intention of fighting—there was a disturbance—a man insulted me, and I took my cane, and told him if he repeated the words again I would put it across his back—I struck him, but he did not strike me—when I first went in I had a glass of soda-water, and a little drop of brandy in it—I was not tipsy; I had not above five wine-glasses of punch while I was there—I did not drink half-and-half—I swear I had not ten glasses of punch; it was rum-and-brandy punch, and small wine
glasses—I had just come off a journey, which made me call there—the prisoner did not say he had found these things of mine till he was at the police-station—he at first refused to be searched.

JOHN LOOKER (policeman, R 295). On 7th Nov., at an early hour in the morning, I was on duty in London-street, Greenwich, and heard a cry of "Police!"—I found the prosecutor with his face, coat, and hat, smothered in flour—he gave the prisoner in charge—I took him to the station, searched him, and found three pairs of gloves, a six-foot measure, and a silk hand
kerchief—he said he found the measure in the White Hart—he did not say anything about the other articles—they were found in a different pocket.

Cross-examined. Q. What time was it? A. A quarter to two o'clock—I do not know whether there had been a disturbance—I did not hear any
thing about the prosecutor refusing to pay for the bowl of punch—he was sober. Witnesses for the Defence.

CHARLES MILLER . I am the conducter of an omnibus, and have been in Mr. Wheatley's service fifteen years—I have known the prisoner twenty years; he is a driver. On this evening, I went into the parlour of the White Hart, and there were two or three gentlemen lying just inside the door on the top of each other—I suppose they had been fighting—Mr. Parry was stand
ing at the further corner of the room, and I saw him cane Mr. Moore, a very respectable old tradesman of Greenwich, with his stick—I think Mr. Parry was in his shirt-sleeves when I went in; I will not be sure; I know he was, some part of the evening—Walker went in with me, and be picked up a gentleman named M'Killan, a wine-merchant; the potman helped—after we came out of the parlour, and the scuffle had been quieted, Mr. French, the landlord, got Mr. Wilcox, another old gentleman, out, and put him in the bar
parlour, and the prisoner said, "I have picked up something; look here," and he rolled it along the counter: it was a tailor's measure, a round thing that wound up, like that produced—the prosecutor wanted to fight again two or three times, and wanted to get to Mr. Wilcox and Mr. Moore, and we would not let him—there had been some disturbance with them about some punch.

JURY. Q. Did the prisoner produce the gloves as well as the measure? A. No; the prosecutor called for the police; they came, and he said, "I give this man into custody for throwing flour on my face," and there was no flour

used that night; it was oatmeal—the prisoner and policemen walked together to the station, and I walked some distance behind, and when he got to the station they asked him if he had anything about him—he said, "Yes; I have got some things I picked up in front of the bar"—he was searched, and when the things were produced, Mr. Parry owned them.

MR. PARRY. Q. In going to the station, was the prisoner kept hold of by the policemen? A No; he had ample time to make away with anything in his possession—when I went into the room, the row was half over; the chairs were all about the place, and four or five children were screaming.

COURT. Q. Do you mean to say that the prisoner said of all the things found on him that he found them in front of the bar? A, Yes; those were the words he made use of at the station, but they might have searched him before he said so.

GEORGE FIFE . I am a bookseller, residing in High-street, Deptford. On this evening I was in the parlour at the White Hart, Greenwich, and saw Mr. Parry, Mr. Wilcox, and Mr. M'Killan there drinking a bowl of punch—a disturbance arose between Mr. Parry and Mr. Moore, an old gentleman, as to the payment for the punch—Mr. Parry was not sober, but had been drink
ing—Mr. Moore said I have nothing at all to do with the punch; I have had my three glasses of gin-and-water, and I shall not pay for any punch—I did not see him drink any—some more words took place, and Mr. Parry said, "You old vagabond, if you don't sit down I will cane you"—he struck him with the cane, and it was broken in the scuffle—I saw Mr. Parry take off his coat and throw it across the table—I suppose he did that to fight—he said to me, "Mind that coat!"—I was sitting down quietly, and took no part in it—I did not see the coat afterwards—he offered to fight, and jumped on the table to do so—I do not know that I was sober—I could fully under
stand all that took place—I afterwards saw the prisoner in charge, in Skelton-street—if he had wanted to get rid of anything he might have done so.

COURT. Q. Were you present when the coat was asked for? A. Yes; it was found in the tap-room, I believe; not the room where the prosecutor was—I was there when Mr. French said Mr. Parry had not brought a coat with him, and I directly said I saw him with his coat—Mr. French came in after he had taken it off—I do not believe he saw it.

MR. PARRY. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. Ten or twelve years; during that time he has borne the character of an industrious honest man—I never knew anything against him before—I have known him as an omnibus-driver—I have kept a bookseller's shop for the last six years, and have lived in the town all my life.

HENRY PARRY
re-examined. It was impossible for the gloves to have fallen out of my pocket, it is so deep—there is no button to it, but it is a small pocket-hole, and the linings go to the bottom—my cane was not thicker than a straw—I did not state next day that I did not recollect anything that took place.

THOMAS MOORE . I am a hay-dealer in Church-street, Greenwich. I was in the parlour at the White Hart—Mr. Parry kept on asking me to give him a shilling towards a bowl of punch—I said I had no objection in joining him in a bowl of punch, but I had had my gin-and-water, and did not want it—he kept on pestering me for the shilling; he went away for about half an hour, came back, and ordered another bowl, and wanted a shilling"—I said I would not have anything to say to him at all—he said," You old vagabond, I will lay my cane about you," and he did; and my friend Wilcox got up

end said, "I will not see my old friend served like this," and he and Mr. Parry went on the ground together—Mr. M'Killan then came up, and he was on the ground too—I was sitting in the chair when he hit me—I am fifty-four years old—I have known the prisoner from a boy—I never heard any
thing against him—his father and grandfather are both respectable.

EDWARD WILCOX . I am a painter, at George-street, Greenwich; I have lived in that street nearly thirty years—I remember Mr. Parry wishing Mr. Moore to pay a portion of a bowl of punch—Mr. Moore objected to it—I did not see him drink any of it—I saw Mr. Parry cane Mr. Moore while he was sitting in his chair—he had done nothing but object to pay for the punch.

Prosecutor, Q. Did you not hear him call me a jackass? A. No; I was not quite sober—I am a frequent customer at that house—I was not so tipsy that I was obliged to sleep there that night, to my recollection; I was tipsy—I have known the prisoner seven or eight years, and never heard anything against him—he is an omnibus driver.

COURT. Q. What kept you up till one o'clock? A. We were a few friends together—when Mr. Parry struck Mr. Moore, I got up to protect him—I saw nothing of the coat. (Other witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

148.
MARY ANN LAWES
, stealing ¼ lb. weight of tea, 4 ounces of sugar, 8 yards of lace, 4 ounces of plate-powder, and two boxes, value 17s.; the goods of
Thomas Whitaker, her master.

JANE WHITAKER . I am the wife of Thomas Whitaker, of Park-terrace, Sydenham. The prisoner was in our service as cook for nine months, and left on 8th Oct.—I then missed some pieces of lace from my bed-room—I had five different patterns of lace—I have some lace here which I have compared with that produced by the officer—I also missed a box like this (produced)—my husband has the Yorkshire Gazette sent to him, and we bad the one dated 4th Aug., we missed a quantity of it while the prisoner was with us—the value of the lace varied from 4s. to 5s. a yard.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Was it some time after she left that you missed the articles? A. About three weeks after she left we missed some preserves, and that induced us to have her boxes searched—I could recognise the lace the moment I saw it, without the pieces which correspond—I had a great quantity of each pattern—it is not an uncommon sort of lace—she did not have to find her own tea—after the Yorkshire Gazette was read, it was used about the house.

HENRY PAYNE (policeman, R 6). I apprehended the prisoner on the 1st Nov., at Mr. Widdon's, on Sydenham-hill—I told her she was charged with stealing some preserves, and other articles—she said she knew nothing about them—I said she must go to the station—I sealed up her boxes at this House, and afterwards fetched them to the station—I then fetched Mrs. Whitaker, and the boxes were opened in the prisoner's presence, and Mrs. Whitaker identified these articles—there were four or five ounces of loaf-sugar wrapped in the Yorkshire Gazette—she said the lace was given her by a former mistress, who was dead.
Cross-examined. Q. How much lace is there? A. About three or four yards—these tin boxes are such as are used in confectioners' shops—I found this box of plate-powder (produced) in her box.

MKS. WHITAKIR
re-examined. I know that box—the lace was taken from me whole, and has been made up into collars and other things since.

ANN BENHAM . My husband is a labourer, at Sydenham—I have known the prisoner eight or nine months, but have known very little of her; she lodged with me three weeks—I always found her sober and honest—after she left Mrs. Whitaker's, I went there to oblige Mrs. Whitaker till she got suited—the tea and sugar I bought for the prisoner on the Saturday as she went to her new situation on the Monday—she was to have 16l. a year, and find her own tea and sugar.
GUILTY . Aged 34.—Strongly Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined One Month ,

149.
SARAH STANTON
, stealing 2 gowns, 1 waistcoat, 1 comb, and other articles, value 3l.; the goods of
Charles Louis Amie De Bergue.

SOPHIA DE BERGUE . I am the wife of Charles Louis Amie De Bergue—I live with my brother Frederick William Billings—the prisoner was our servant—on the 18th Nov., in consequence of missing some articles, I went into her bed-room, and found two silk dresses of mine between the mattress and the bed—I told my brother; and in the evening I charged the prisoner with stealing them—she produced a comb of mine out of her pocket—she was taken into custody; and next day I went with the sergeant to the Servants'-Home in Millman-street—some boxes were opened there, in there prisoner's presence—she had given us the keys the night before, hoping that we should not give her into custody, and said we should have the things back—I found two handkerchiefs, two neck-ties, and a pair of scissors of mine—I missed a coat of my husband's, and five tea-spoons, which I found in a drawer, into which a box of my mother's had been emptied—the clothes have not been found—she was only with me a few days.

JOHN MAY (policeman). On 15th Nov. I took the prisoner—I received some keys from Mrs. De Bergue, and went with her and her brother to the Servants'-Home—I opened some boxes which the prisoner had described to me, and found this lace, handkerchiefs, and ornament (produced); and between her bed and mattress I found these two dresses—the value of the whole is 7l. or 8l

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined One Year.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

150.
MARIA CRONIN ,
JOHN BROWN ,
THOMAS JONES , and
MARGARET THOMPSON were indicted for
unlawfully uttering counter
feit coin. MESSRS. BODKIN and DAWSON conducted the Prosecution.

SARAH HAGGERTY . I am the wife of James Haggerty, and am servant to Mr. West, at the Marquis of Granby, High-street, Woolwich. On 18th Nov., about half-past eight o'clock, the prisoners came and had a pot of por
ter, and some bread and butter—I served them; they gave me 1s.—the two women went out, and returned again in about ten minutes—they stopped till ten, and all went away together.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you know them? A. No; I did not notice the womens dress.

SARAH HARRISS MURRAY . I am the wife of John Money Murray, tobacconist; of Woolwich. On 18th Nov., between eight and nine o'clock at night, Cronin came for half an ounce of tobacco, it came to 1 1/2 d.—she gave me a crown-piece, which was bad—I told her so—she said she was not aware of it, a man gave it her, and she would leave a mug which she had and fetch him—I allowed her to go, and kept the crown-piece—a policeman came, I marked it, and gave it to him.
ANN BINKS . I am the wife of William Binks, a chandler, of High-street,

Woolwich. On 18th Nov., Brown came in without hit jacket or bat, and asked for a quarter of a pound of Dutch cheese, and a quarter of an ounce of tobacco—I gave them to him—he threw down a crown-piece—I gave him 4s.6 1/2 d. change—he took it up very quickly, and ran to the door—I followed him with the crown-piece, and saw him take his jacket and bat from Cronin—the two other prisoners joined them opposite my shop, and all four went up the street together—I marked the crown-piece, and gave it to the policeman.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen Brown before? A. No; but I could not keep my eyes off him—he seemed so agitated—I picked him out the same night at a lodging-house where the four were.
JOHN GRIFFIN (policeman, R 229). I received this bad crown-piece (produced) from Mrs. Murray.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you kept it ever since? A. Yes; she marked it before she gave it me.

JOHN WALKER (policeman, R 298). On Sunday, 18th Nov., I was called to Mrs. Birch's—she gave me this crown-piece (produced)—I took her to Mr. Muskett's lodging-house, and found two men and three women—she pointed out Brown—he said he knew nothing about it—I told Cronin that I should take her from her description, and told her what for—she said, "I have not been in the shop at all"—I took them to the station, sent for Mrs. Murray, and she pointed out Cronin—I found on Brown five shillings, five sixpences, and sixpence, in copper all good.

HANNAH MANN . I am servant to William Muskett, who keeps a lodging-house at Woolwich. On 18th Nov. the prisoners came, and Brown asked for a lodging—they sent for a pot of porter—I fetched it, and on my return found a policeman there—he took Brown and Cronin—Cronin pointed to Jones, when the policeman's back was turned to the back of the table, and Jones took something black or brown from under the table, and made towards the door; I collared him, and he threw it over the adjoining fence.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he clench it in his hand? A. After looking at it—I collared him because he was going to leave a drunken female in the house.

ROBERT GREEN . I keep a lodging-house, two doors from Mr. Muskett's; on the morning of 19th I found four counterfeit crown-pieces in my back garden, tied up in this piece of black silk—I took them to the station—a per
son can throw anything there from Mr. Muskett's.

JAMES PARRV (police-sergeant, R 8). I received these four crown-pieces and this piece of silk from Green—Walker brought Jones to the sta
tion—I searched him and found this piece of silk, which corresponds with the other in texture, and by some stitches—also five shillings, three sixpences, and fivepence in halfpence.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you take Jones? A. He was in custody when I was sent for—he was waiting outside the police-court, which is next to the station, to hear the result of the other prisoners' examination, and was taken.
JOHN KEMPSTER . These crown-pieces are all bad, and are of the reign Geo. III., 1820—I believe they are all cast in one mould, by three indentations on them.

CRONIN—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Nine Months.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Nine Months.

THOMPSON—
NOT GUILTY .

151.
JAMES CHAPMAN
, stealing 1 watch and guard, 7l. 10s., 1 half-crown, seven shillings and sixpence; the goods of
Hugh M'Clelland.

HUGH MCCLELLAND . I am a corporal of artillery—the prisoner was gunner in the same corps, and occupied the same room as me. On 22d Nov., at half-past eight o'clock in the morning, I left my quarters, leaving my watch and guard, and eight or ten shillings safe in my box, which was locked, and I kept the key—the prisoner was there when I left—I came back, between ten and eleven—the prisoner was gone—he ought to have stayed to take care of the room—my box was broken open, and I missed my watch and money; this is the watch (produced)—the prisoner never came back, but was appre
hended by the police.
JOHN THORP . I am in the service of John Moore, a pawnbroker, of Woolwich—this watch was pledged by the prisoner on 22d Nov., in the name of "James Chapman," he said it was his own.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Twelve Months.

152.
JOSEPH OSMOTHERLY and
SUSANNAH JOHNSON
steal
ing 1 box, 8 gowns, 5 shifts, 3 night gowns, 3 shawls, 1 coffee-pot and other articles, value 3l. 7s. 2d.; the goods of
Ann Thompson.

ANN THOMPSON . I am single—I did live with Osmotherly till I went into Guy's Hospital, five weeks ago, through illness. We lived at 15, Henry-street, Woolwich—when I left, I left my box of clothes packed up, locked, and corded, with Mrs. Cheeseman, who lodged in the house, ready to travel by the carrier—I left some directions with it—Osmotherly said he would call for it, and send it by the carrier to my brother at Hounslow; it had a packing-case sewed all round it; and when I saw it again it was broken open in this way (produced)—there are two dresses, four yards of print, a pair of boots, a pair of shoes, three yards calico, four handkerchiefs, two brushes, and other things now missing—there was a coffee-pot in the box, wrapped up in the lining of an old dress; this is it (produced)—I did not authorise any one to open the box or take anything out.

JANI CHEESEMAN . I am the wife of Thomas Cheeseman, of Henry-street, Woolwich—Thompson lodged in the same house, she left this box in my care with some directions—in three weeks' time Osmotherly came, said he was just come out of barracks and wanted the box, for his brother was waiting down at the battalion, and he wanted to send it to London to Thompson.—I gave it him—it was then in the same state as when Thompson left it with me.
Osmotherly. Q. Can you swear it was me fetched it? A. Yes; I looked out at the window, and saw you go off with it on your shoulder.

GBOKGE SUTTON (policeman, R 49). On 11th Nov., I went to a house in Limery-buildings, Woolwich, and in the kitchen found the prisoners and an
other marine, and the box and contents, the lid was broken off and the things strewed about the room—Osmotherly was in the act of looking into a tea-caddy in the box—I asked him whose property it was—he said his wife's, she was going to make use of it—he then said it was Ann Thompson's, whom he had been living with—I asked how it was broken open—he said he was in such a passion, he broke it open—I saw a coffee-pot lying by the side of the fire wrapped up in a piece of linen—I asked who it belonged to—Johnson said it was hers—I took them both to the stations, and on the way Osmotherly said, if he did not get locked up he would have a spree with the things next day.

Osmotherly's Defence. Thompson told me she had left the box; she wrote to me to send it to London, and I asked a man the price to take it, and he told me if I would take it to the corner we should not fall out about the price; I fetched it to the corner, and. the sentry told me the carman had been gone about twenty minutes; I went to a public-house, and put the box in the parlour; I afterwards took it, and it fell off my back and burst open; I took it to the railway station, and put it upon a wall; the policeman was behind me, and some of the things fell out in the street; I took them under my arm, and a mate and this woman came along and I asked them to assist me; the man said he was going to stop out all night, and the box would be all right if we took it into this house; we took it in, and in about twenty minutes Sutton came and asked where I got it from, and I told him; I said it was the first time I was ever in custody, and if I got out I would have a spree for it; the other marine told me the policeman followed me.
Johnsons Defence, He brought the box to my place, and asked to let it remain there till the morning.

GEORGE SUTTON
re-examined, I did not follow them—there were three hours from the time the box was moved till I found it—I never saw it before I saw it in the room.
(Charles Hancock, sergeant of the Marine Artillery, gave Osmotherly a good character.)

OSMOTHERLY—
GUILTY . Aged 26—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Six Months. JOHNSON—
NOT GUILTY .

153.
WILLIAM JACKSON and
HENRY ROGERS
, stealing 87 lbs. weight of lead, value 16s.; the goods gf
John Blyth, fixed to a building. MR. PAYNE conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN BENNEY (policeman, R 356). On Wednesday night, 31st Oct., I was in the Woolwich-road, at a quarter before ten o'clock—I heard a noise in an unfinished house there—I looked up and saw Jackson at the attic-window—I went to the back of the house, and found Rogers in a trench, made in the area—I asked him what he was doing there—he said he came for a neces
sary purpose—Jackson was still at the window—I asked Rogers if he knew there was any one up there—he said he did not—I told Jackson to come down, and he did—I asked him what he was doing up there—he said, "Nothing"—I took them into the road, and said they must come with me—Rogers made his escape—I took Jackson to the station—in going, he said he had been there, and cut off about 6 lbs. of lead, and I should find it at the back of the house—I locked him up, and gave a description of Rogers to another officer, and he was brought in about half-past two—after I had locked Jackson up, I went back to the house—I found another officer there who had found the lead that was cut off—I matched it, and it fitted to the roof—there was about 8 lbs. of lead found on the ground, near where Rogers had been—I matched that with the lead on the roof, and it all matched—I found three-quarters of a cwt. more lead on the top cut off ready to throw down.
WILLIAM NOSEWORTHY (policeman, R 324). I went to the house and found the lead—I helped to match it to the place; it came from there.

FREDERICK COTTON (policeman, R 110). I took Rogers into custody, at half-past two o'clock in the morning, about three-quarters of a mile from the houses—I found him asleep—I told him I must take him, for stealing lead from some unfinished buildings—he said he knew nothing about them—I
passed the houses with him, and pointed them out—he said he had not seen the houses before, and knew nothing about the lead.
JOHN BLYTH . These houses are mine; the lead on them belonged to me

JACKSON—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

ROGERS—
GUILTY Aged 28.

154.
JAMES WILSON
, stealing 2 pair of boots, value 5s.; the goods of
John Cooper, and 59 yards of twilling, 1l., 14s. 6d.; the goods of
Hem Drake and another: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

155.
JONATHAN POINTING and
WILLIAM GRAY
, stealing 2 boots, value 5s.; the goods of
William Henry Sullivan and another.

WILLIAM HENRY SULLIVAN . I live in Powis-street, Woolwich. I keep a shoe-shop with my brother—I was in the back-kitchen about half-past four o'clock on 20th Nov., I heard a cry, and ran down Union-street—I saw a marine about fifty yards in advance, with two boots in his hand—I stopped him, and took them from him—I do not know who the person was—I have no belief on the subject—these are my boots; they are two odd ones.

JAMES WARREN . I am nine years old. On that afternoon I saw Pointing pull the two boots down, and give them to the other prisoner, and he went off—Mr. Sullivan came after him, took him, and took the boots from him; it was not so dark but he could have seen him if he had looked.
JOSEPH SMITH . I saw Mr. Sullivan run after the prisoner, Gray, and take the boots from him; it was light enough for me to see him.
Gray. I never had the pair of boots in my bands.

POINTING—
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Nine Months.

GRAY—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Nine Months

156.
JONATHAN POINTING was again indicted
for stealing 1 hand
kerchief, value 25.; the goods of
Samuel Taylor, from his person.

SAMUEL TAYLOR . On Tuesday afternoon, 20th Nov., I was in the tap-room of the George and Dragon public-house—the prisoner was there—I had my handkerchief taken out of my pocket, which had been safe not many minutes before—this is it.
Prisoner. Q. Was I in your company? A, You were in the room.
GEORGE WILLIAM WATERS . I am a pawnbroker. This handkerchief was pawned with me on 20th Nov. by the prisoner; it was redeemed afterwards by some one else.
JOSEPH HYDE . On the night of 20th Nov. I bought the duplicate of this handkerchief of the prisoner,
Prisoner's Defence. I gave a shilling for the duplicate, and went to pawn the handkerchief again, and they would not give me but eightpence for it; I then sold the duplicate again.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Transported for Seven Years. (The sergeant of Marines stated that both the prisoners had very bad characters, and Pointing had been tried five times by a Court-martial.)

157.
CORNELIUS SHAW
, stealing 33 lbs. weight of coals, valued; the goods of
Alfred Ritchie.

JOSEPH LING . I am in the service of Mr. Alfred Ritchie, at Deptford. On 4th Nov., about half-past seven o'clock, I was watching my master's coal barges—I saw some boys taking the coals off the barges and putting them in a bag—I started after them between the barges—they ran to the other end—I
ran round and caught the prisoner, who had got thirty-three pounds of coals which belonged to Mr. Ritchie—the other boy got away.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not steal them; I have no father, and nobody to look after me but my mother; she is a widow and has six children; I am the eldest.

GUILTY .** Aged 16.—
Confined Seven Days and
Whipped.

158.
JOHN HARDY
, stealing 2 watches, value 7l.; the property of
William Chester, in his dwelling-house.

REBECCA CHESTER . I am the wife of William Chester. On 29th Sept. I had an eating-house in Woolwich—the prisoner was lodging in the house—I had these two watches at the bottom of a large box in my bed-room—they were in this small box which was broken open—this is one of them—I missed them on the 18th Oct.—I removed from that house—I spoke to the prisoner and said I had missed them, and all I had to depend upon with my children and my sick husband was my two watches, to sell to open another shop at Greenwich—he said, "Never mind, your luck' will all turn at once"—he wanted breakfast that morning—I would not let him have it—he had not above 2s. when he came to my house, nine days before—he owed me 1l—I went out, and when 1 came back he pulled 15s. out of his pocket—he said he had been to his barracks and sold his boots; and he bought himself tome civilian clothing that afternoon, and disguised himself—he was taken to the barracks with those clothes on—there was no other soldier in my house but him—he went in my bed-room to get these.
Prisoner. Q. Was that the first time I had been in your bed-room? A. No, you had been there before.
GEORGE WILLIAM WATERS . I am a pawnbroker—this watch was pawned at my employer's shop by a person very much resembling the prisoner—I believe it was him.
Prisoner. Q. Are you sure I was the person? A. I believe you to be the person.
Prisoner's Defence. I have been four years in the regiment, and had a good character; I am not guilty of the charge against me.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined One Year.

159.
WILLIAM STOKES
, feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 125. with intent to defraud
Jonathan Russell.

JOHN MILLS . On Friday morning, 9th Nov., I was in Greenwich—I met the prisoner—he called to me and said, "Jack, will you take this letter down to the Fisherman's Arms and bring back a blank?"—I agreed to do so—he gave me a letter; I took it to the Fishermans' Arms—I cannot read or write, but it was folded like a letter, like this—(looking at a letter)—I saw Mr. Russell at the Fisherman's Arms, and a lady—I gave the letter to the lady and she gave it to Mr. Russell—I received a blank, which was open, from the lady—Mr. Russell was present—I took the blank to the prisoner—there was printing on it—the prisoner gave me a halfpenny and then left.

Prisoner. Q. Can you swear to me? A. Yes, by your face—you were dressed in a corduroy jacket and a hat—I have seen other persons working at Mr. Payne's warehouse in a corduroy jacket—I can swear it was you who gave me the halfpenny.
MR. PARRY. Q. You heard him speak? A. Yes; I saw him again on
the Saturday in the station—he was with other men—I pointed him out immediately—when he spoke to me I saw his face very plainly—my name is John—I do not know how the prisoner knew my name.

JONATHAN RUSSELL . I keep the Fisherman's Arms, in Cold Bath-street, Greenwich, at the corner of Morden-street—on 9th Nov., a boy, who I should not know again, came between ten and twelve o'clock—Mrs. Russell sent a note of a declaration up-stairs—I came down and found the boy waiting—this is the note (looking at it) that was sent up-stairs—I came down and tore the corner off a blank, and gave it to Mrs. Russell—the blanks are kept in a corner.

Prisoner. Q. Do not you tear them all off in the same way? A, Yes; I do not swear to this—I gave four out that week, and this is one of them—I cannot speak to this being the same I gave Mrs. Russell—I have every reason to believe it is—she passed it over to the boy in my presence.

MR. PARRY. Q. When did you see the boy again? A. On the Wed
nesday following—the paper was brought to me the same day, about twelve o'clock, by John Flaxty, wrapped in a bit of paper—William Cornwell was present at the time—he is one of the visitors—I gave him the paper directly, and he said it was a counterfeit—David Anderson is a member of the com
pany, and there are about 400 others—in consequence of what Mr. Corn-well said, Flaxtey was taken that evening—I did not see the prisoner till he was brought into Court before the Magistrate—the paper was brought to me folded up as this is now.

JOHN FLAXTEY . I live in King's-street, Lewisham-road, and am a smith I have known the prisoner for some years—on 9th Nov. I saw him at the Coach and Horses public-house, about ten minutes before twelve o'clock—Mallett was there—the prisoner came in—we were saying we had had no breakfast, we should like to have a bit of bread and cheese—the prisoner said) "I have just turned a shilling job away; a woman has asked me to take a club paper to the Fisherman's Arms, but as I am a member I do not like to take it myself"—we spoke out directly and said, "I will go; I will go"—the prisoner went out of the house and came back directly with a note, and gave it to me—it was wrapped up in a piece of newspaper like this one—I took it, and gave the paper he gave me to Mr. Russell over the bar—Mr. Cornwell was there at the time—Mr. Russell opened it, looked at it, and gave it to Mr. Cornwell, and he said it was counterfeit—I said I knew nothing about it, but William Stokes, a member of the club, gave it me, and he was up at the Coach and Horses, he had better see him—I went back to the Coach and Horses—I saw the prisoner there, and told him it was a counterfeit—he ran out of the house directly, after this woman, as he said—he did not find her—I was taken into custody—I have always given this account of it, as near as I can remember.

WILLIAM CORNWELL . I am a labourer, at 6, North Pole-place, Green
wich-road—I am a member of the United Brotherly Society—I am a steward and visitor—I was in the Fisherman's Arms on 9th Nov., about five minutes to twelve o'clock—I remember Flaxty coming in—he produced this order-Mr. Russell took it and gave it to me—this signature, "William Cornwell," is not my writing—I did not authorize any one to sign it for me—there is no other person of the same name belonging to the Society—five stewards sign on the back of the paper, and one on the front—I asked Flaxty where he got it—he said from the prisoner—no part of this is my writing—the prisoner came into the house shortly afterwards—I asked him how he came by that order—he told me a woman gave it him, with a red plaid shawl—I went with him up the bath and to the foot of Blackheath Hill—I found no woman in

such a dress—he went down two streets, and came to me again, and said he could not find the woman—I said it was strange he could not find a woman who was waiting for the said 12s.—I then went to the Coach and Horses and saw Flaxty—the prisoner said, "Billy to-day was not the day for your visiting"—I said, "No, to-morrow, hut to-day was my day if I thought proper to go to visit"—I left them in the Coach and Horses—I went to No. 12, Church-street, Lee—I did not find any person named John Jones there.
Prisoner, Q. Did I not see you about ten o'clock in the morning? A. Yes; you did not ask me if you were fined for a steward.

GEORGE WITHERSBY . I reside in Bridge-street, Greenwich, and am secretary to the New United Brotherly Society. The prisoner has been a member of the society since 1840—he has been a steward and visitor—he can write a middling handwriting, and as visitor he would be acquainted with the laws of the society—there is no member of the society named John Jones, or James Wood—the names on this declaration are false—I believe it is the pri
soner's writing—this certificate of a surgeon named Dowling, and the signa
ture of Mr. Cornwell I believe to be the prisoner's writing—I believe the names on the back to be forged—I know the handwriting of the persons whose names are here—my brother's name is one—that is not my brother's writing, nor Mr. Gilbert's writing, nor the others.
COURT. Q. Do you believe all the names at the back to be the prisoner's writing? A. Yes; I do—there ought to have been John Matthews, the sixth steward's name, but that is omitted.
Prisoner. You have not seen me write for five or six years. Witness, No, but I have got vouchers, by which he has claimed relief from the society, as lately as act. last, and have acted upon them.

WILLIAM ALFRED MONK . I live in Wellington-place, Lower-road, Deptford. I am one of the stewards of the society—I know the prisoner, and know his handwriting—I have seen him write—this declaration of sickness I believe to be his writing—the writing on the face of this order, and at the back of it, I believe to be his—my name is at the back of it—that is not my writing.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-sergeant, R 38). I apprehended the prisoner between ten and eleven o'clock on 9th Nov.—I told him he was charged with uttering a forged order for the payment of 12s., with intend to defraud the United Brotherly Society—I cautioned him as to anything he might say, as I might give it in against him—he said it was a bad job, but he met a woman who asked him to take this order to the society's house for payment, and he told her as he was a member he did not like to take it—I searched his house, and in a box there 1 found part of the Novel newspaper, which goes on to page 89, and this piece of newspaper handed to me by the witness is page 90—it was blotted with blue ink—this envelope is stained with blue ink—the order is written in blue ink, and I found some pens at the prisoner's which had been used with blue ink—the prisoner was asked if he could read or write, he aid he could not—Flaxty was asked, and he said he could, and he was asked to write his name, which he did—I have since that seen the prisoner write in the cell—I am quite sure I saw him write—he was down on his knees when I rent to fetch him out—he was writing on the back of an envelope—(declaration read—" Sir,—Please to inform the stewards of the New United Brotherly Society that I am incapable of following my employ, and therefore declare on he funds of this society. John Jones, 12, Church-street")—(certificate read "To the stewards of the New United Brotherly Society. I hereby certify hat James Wood continues ill of inflammation of the hand, and is using the roper means for his recovery. William Dowling.")—(order read—" Mr.
Russell,—Please to pay James Wood, or bearer 12s., due this 9th Nov., 1849, William Cornwell."

JONATHAN RUSSELL
re-examined. I am treasurer of this society—if this had been a genuine order, I should have been bound to pay it—they leave money in my hands to pay these orders.

Prisoner's Defence. Any one that takes a note like this could get it just the same as 1 could, if I was on the box; I believe Cornwell to be the cause of it all; I never could do it myself; I was never brought up to it; I have a wife and five children.
GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Nine Months.

160.
THOMAS SMITH SANDWELL
, stealing 1 coat, value 5s.; the goods of
William Fowler: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined Nine Months.

161.
PATRICK KELLY and
MARTIN KELLY
, stealing 1 cheese, value 2s.; 3 shillings, 5 sixpences, 2 pence, 4 halfpence, and 8 farthings; the property of
William Farebrother.

ELIZA FAREBROTHER . I am the wife of William Farebrother, grocer and cheesemonger. On 9th Nov., about seven o'clock in the evening, I received information—I went into the shop, and found the till on the floor, empty—I had seen it ten minutes before, with shillings, sixpences, and copper in it—a Dutch cheese was gone from the window—this is it—I have no doubt it is mine—this red mark was on it before.

CHARLES EDWARD FAREBROTHER. I am nine years old. On that Friday evening I came from the parlour to the shop—I went round the counter, and saw Patrick Kelly take the money—he was kneeling down—I am sure he if the boy.

JOHN WHITE (policeman, R 180). I saw the prisoners coming in a direc
tion from the prosecutor's—Martin Kelly had the cheese under his arm—I followed them—they saw me, and Martin turned and put it into a grocer's door—I took it, and took him—he said he knew nothing about it, the boy that was with him gave it him to carry—I found on him 2s. 8d.—I found Patrick under the bed—I took him to the station, and Martin said that was the boy that gave it him.
Patrick Kelly. I took the cheese, and gave it to him to carry; I know nothing about the money.

PATRICK KELLY—
GUILTY .** Aged 13.—
Confined Three Months.

MARTIN KELLY—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Two Months.

162.
WILLIAM FAREN
, stealing 36 lbs. weight of gun metal, value 12s.; the goods of
Bennett Alfred Burton and another his masters: to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15; he received a good character, and was re
commended to mercy.—
Confined Seven days.

163.
HANNAH SHEEN and
ELLEN HURLEY
, stealing 1 purse, value 1 shilling, 4 sovereigns, and 2 half sovereigns; the property of
James Rougier, from his person.
JAMES ROUGIER . I am captain of the Queen Victoria, and live at 139 1l. 2, Cheapside. On 2d Nov. I was coming out of a public-house in the Borough

with a friend at half-past twelve o'clock at night; the prisoners came up to us and asked us to go home with them—they took as to a house up a court, we had some drink; I paid for it—Sheen then asked me to sleep with her—I refused, I gave her a parting kiss and left—a person spoke to me, and I missed my purse, containing four sovereigns, two half sovereigns, and some silver—the policeman ran after the two prisoners and brought them back—I charged them with stealing my purse—I had it in the house when I paid for the drink, not a minute before I left—I was not tipsy, but something was put into my spirits—I was not exactly what I ought to be—no one else had the opportunity of taking it—I had not been out of the house three minutes—I paid nothing for the room—I do not know whether my friend did.

Cross-examined by MR. WOOLLET. Q. Were not you very drunk? A, No; I could walk—my friend keeps the boarding-house where I live—I had only been to one public-house since my tea—I remained there till it closed, about three hours—I did not drink above two glasses of brandy and water—my friend was not drunk or sober—we met the prisoners very near the Grapes—we had some brandy afterwards at the house; I paid two shillings for it—I saw no other girls there—we remained there half or three-quarters of an hour—I was told that I had dropped my purse there—whether I did or not I cannot say, but I had it when I left.

MARIA BERRY . I am a widow, of 2, St. Margaret's-court, Borough; my house receives temporary lodgers for accommodation. On 2d Nov., between two and three o'clock, the prisoners came with Rougier and another man—Rougier sent me out for some brandy, and gave me the money for it—they staid three-quarters of an hour, to the best of my recollection—as he went out of the parlour be dropped his purse, it was a small spring one—Sheen picked it up and gave it to him, and he put it in his left trowsers pocket—I heard the money chink—I requested to look at the purse; and he handed it to me—the spring was tight—I returned it to him—he had it all right when he left my house.

Cross-examined, Q. How many rooms have you? A. Four bed-rooms and two parlours—I am only housekeeper there—the establishment consists of myself and a maid-servant—I fetched in a quartern of brandy and a quartern of rum—the purse was dropped in the back parlour—the captain did not go up-stairs; his friend did with Sheen, but they could not agree, and came down immediately—he was very drunk, but the captain was not so tipsy

HENRY THOMAS (policeman, M 64). Last Thursday morning, between two and three o'clock, I saw Sheen come out of Mrs. Berry's house with the captain, they went into a dark corner of the court, twelve or fourteen yards from the door—Hurley went after them; they remained about three minutes—I saw them go away from him—he came and told me something, and I went after the prisoners, and stopped them about two hundred yards off in Redcross-street—I said they were charged with robbing a man in the alley—they said, "Very well," they would come back with me—Sheen dropped half-a-sovereign in Fishmonger-alley; my brother constable picked it up and gave it to me (produced)—I found this, sovereign and two shillings (produced) in the pocket of Sheen's gown—I took them to the station.

ANN LONGHURST . I am one of the female searchers of Newgate. Sheen was brought here last Saturday evening—I searched her and found a sovereign at the bottom of her dress, wrapped up in a little bit of leather, between the dress and the lining—it was not fastened, it could not have dropped there—I gave it to the turnkey. JAMES ROUGIER re-examined. Mine was a small spring purse like that

described, similar to this (producing one)—nobody could see that there was money in it—I did not look in it when Mrs. Berry returned it to me, to see that my money was correct.
NOT GUILTY .

164.
JANE MARSHALL
, stealing 3 handkerchiefs, 1 pair of stockings, and other articles, value 5 shillings; the goods of
John Whitcher, her master; having been before convicted.

SARAH WHITCHER . I am the wife of John Whitcher, of Bengal-terrace, Old Kent-road—the prisoner came into my service about ten weeks ago—I wrote for her character, and did not get it—she remained a little more than two months—I missed three cigars out of the parlour—she denied having them—she afterwards gave them to me out of her pocket—next day I looked in her box, and found a pair of stockings, a piece of lace, and two handker
