chiefs—she said the stockings and lace were mine, but not the handkerchiefs—she packed up her boxes and went away without them—I opened the boxes and took the handkerchiefs out—I saw this satin handkerchief at the police-court—it is mine, and has my mark upon it—the things are worth 5s. altogether.
MARY ANN RANDALL . I am the wife of a policeman, and search females at the station—I searched the prisoner, and found two half-crowns in her hand, and afterwards a satin handkerchief in her box.
WILLIAM ROSS (policeman). I produce a pair of stockings, some lace, and three cigars.

SARAH WHITCHER
re-examined, I believe these to be mine, I swear to the stockings.

Prisoner's Defence, I was keeping company with a young man, and tookc three cigars for him; I did not know it was wrong; my master forgave me, and told me to go on as though nothing had happened; I put things not belonging to my department into my box for security when I was left in charge of the house, and I had so much to do I had not time to look over my box; I had plenty of opportunity to be dishonest if I wished; I was left in charge of the house with money and a watch, and when my mistress came from the country she appeared very much pleased; I said, "If you will wait till I earn the money I will give it you;" she said, "That proves you guilty;" this is all done out of spite, because I left her service.

SARAH WHITCHER
re-examined. When I went out of town I gave her 1l. 17s. 6d., in case she wanted anything; but the money was all marked, and she knew it; at least we showed her one marked coin—I have missed things and money before, but did not suspect her till I missed the cigars.

ALEXANDER TAHOURDIN (policeman, L 57) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction—(ready, Convicted Dec, 1847, of stealing from her master, having been before convicted; confined eighteen months)—she had been out of pri
son three or four weeks when she went to this place—she was also convicted in Nov., 1846, for robbing her mistress.
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined One Year , (There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

165.
RICHARD IVE
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Robert Baker, on 7th Nov., at Lambeth, and stealing 1 seal, 1 coat, 2 frocks, and other articles, value 3l. 10s., his property:—also,
for stealing in the dwelling-house of
Robert Baker, on 14th Sept., 1 coat and other articles, value 3l. 17s., 4 shillings, and 1 sixpence, his property; and after
wards burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house: to which be pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Ten Years.

166.
JAMES MAY
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Thomas, and stealing 1 stone bottle and 5 quarts of brandy, value 25s.; his property; having been twice before convicted of felony.
MR. PARRY conducted the Prosecution,

ANN THOMAS . I am the daughter of John Thomas, who keeps the Coach and Horses, in Broad-street, Lambeth. On the afternoon of 6th Nov., between two and three o'clock, I saw the prisoner and another man at our house—the prisoner came to the kitchen-door and asked if my father was at home—I said he was not in the way—he went into the tap-room, the floor of which forms the ceiling of the cellar—I did not see the other man go in—I afterwards heard a dancing and great noise in the tap-room—I sent the potman to see what it was—he called me, and I looked in and saw a hole made in the tap-room floor—I did not say anything, but retired to the bar and watched—the noise ceased—I then went to the door, and found it either fastened or some one standing against it inside—my father returned about this time—I then went to the street-door and saw the prisoner running up the street with the brandy in his hand—I had not seen him go out—I ran after him, caught him, and brought him back—he said, "It is all right, I have only got a drop of beer"—my father came up, and he was taken.
Prisoner. Q. What did I say when I came in and asked if your father was at home? A. You asked if I would trust you with a pint of beer.

SARAH TRIBE . I live with my mother a widow, at 8, New-street, Lambeth. On the afternoon of 6th Nov., I was passing Mr. Thomas' house, and saw the prisoner come out—he went to the tap-room window where there was a pane of glass open, and I saw a man give him a bottle out—he walked away with it—I saw Miss Thomas come out and fetch him back.

JOHN THOMAS . I keep the Coach and Horses—I returned home a little after three—I heard a noise at the door, and saw my daughter holding the prisoner by the collar—I said, "What is the matter?"—she said, "father, they have been robbing the cellar"—I then said to the prisoner, "You have been having a bit of a lark here"—he said, "Do not hurt me Thomas, I did not mean any harm"—the policeman came, and he was given into custody—the house is in the parish of Lambeth; I rent it—the bottle contained about five quarts of brandy.
Prisoners Defence. I was so intoxicated that I did not know what I was doing; I have endeavoured to get an honest living.
WILLIAM THOMAS BRIDGES (police-inspector). I produce a certificate—(read—James May, convicted April, 1848, and confined six months)—I was present, the prisoner is the person convicted.
JOSEPH JOHN LEWIS (police-inspector). I produce a certificate—(read—James May, Convicted Sept., 1842, transported for seven years)—I was present, the prisoner is the person convicted.

GUILTY .** Aged 32.—
Transported for Ten Years.

167.
ELLEN LANE and
MARGARET SULLIVAN , were indicted for
a robbery on
Agnes Cornelly, and stealing 1 half-crown, 1 sixpence, 1 groat, and 6 pence; her property: Lane having been before convicted.

AGNES CORNELLY . I live at 10, Fox-buildings. On 30th Oct., rather early in the morning, I went into a public-house in the Borough, to have something to drink; I do not know the name of it, but believe it is the Crown—the prisoners were standing by the door—I took out my money in the

public-house, and folded it in a piece of paper, and put it in my bosom on my left breast—I do not know whether the prisoners could see it—when I went out they followed me, knocked me down some how or other on my elbows, and broke the bone of my stays—Sullivan held me, and the other took the money—there was a half-crown, one shilling, sixpence, and a four-penny piece.

Sullivan. Q. Did not you say you had two half-crowns? A. No; I told the inspector that I was robbed on a coffee-house step, they sell coffee at this house—I did not state I was robbed from my left pocket.

JOSEPH SMITH. I live at 16, Royal-street, Lambeth, and am a fireman. On 30th Oct., about six o'clock in the morning, I was standing outside the Crown door, and saw Sullivan follow Cornelly—she shoved her and feel on her—Lane came out immediately and took some money from her, but what I cannot say—I heard some drop, and there was a scrambling after it—Lane went in and passed something to two young men—they then all came out and went away together—I told them if I saw a constable I would give them in custody—I did not see them again till the following Saturday—I am quite certain of the prisoners—I know them well.

Lane. Q. You saw me pass the money? A. I did; some of the money fell under the prosecutrix's clothes, and you scrambled about for it. Sullivan. Q. Were there any other females there? A. No. BARTHOLOMEW HAGGERTY. I am a bricklayer's labourer, and live in Tooley-street. On 30th Oct., at six o'clock in the morning, I was in High-street—I saw the two prisoners in the public-house and some more besides—the prosecutrix came in—I saw the prisoners follow her out, and lay hold of the money, and take it from her—I saw her on the ground—Sullivan laid hold of her—I wanted to prevent her from taking it, and she took a hair-pin out of her head, and wanted to strike me with it.
Sullivan. Q. Did not you offer me three shillings to go home with you? A. No; you wanted to drink with me, and I refused.

Sullivan's Defence. Between four and five o'clock we were standing near St. George's Church; being destitute and without a lodging, a gentleman gave us a shilling; and we went into the house to have some coffee, the prosecutrix was there and the man; she said she was robbed on a coffee-house step.

JOHN HAWTON (policeman). I produce a certificate—(read—Ellen Reed, convicted Oct., 18-18, confined six months)—Lane is that person. LANE—
GUILTY . Aged 21
.—Transported for Ten Years.
SULLIVAN—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

168.
JOHN CUMMINS ,
EDWARD DONOVAN , and
HENRY MORGAN , were indicted for
a robbery on
William Bevan, and stealing from his person 1 bag, value 2d., and 16s.; his property.

WILLIAM BEVAN . I am a sailor. On 28th Nov. about ten o'clock at night, I saw the prisoners in a public-house at Dockhead—they asked me to treat them, and I did so, and changed a sovereign—I put my change in a bag in my right trowsers pocket—I then had sixteen shillings in it, in half-crowns and shillings; it was mostly shillings—there was one new one—when I came out, I met two women; I asked them where I could get a lodging—the pri
soners followed us—Cummins caught hold of me on one side and Morgan on the other—I said, "I will not have anything to do with you, if that is the way you are going on"—they said if I would give them a pint of gin they would keep clear of me—I went back and treated them—I came out again

and they followed me—when we got to the lodging outside the door, Cum
mings struck me in the face—I fell with my head against the step of the door, and my senses were gone—I knew nothing more after that—when I came to, my bag and money were gone—I was not sober.

JANE SMITH . I and another female were with Be van; the prisoners came up—I knew Cummins and Morgan—they would insist on following us—at the lodging-house door Cummins pushed the sailor down by his shoulder—he did not strike him—he struck his head on the kerb—Donovan and Morgan were on each side of him with their hands in his pockets, while Cummins held his head between his legs—I fetched a policeman, and gave them in charge.

PHOEBE ANN HUNT . I was with Smith and Bevan. The prisoners fol
lowed us—when we got to the lodging, Cummins came behind Bevan and pulled him down by the shoulders—his bead struck the stones—Cummins held him, while the other two went to his trowsers pockets—we ran for a policeman.

WILLIAM TOWERSE (policeman, M 38). About half-past ten o'clock I was on duty, and saw the prisoners on each side of Bevan, and one walking behind—he was the worse for liquor—they were sober—about a quarter before twelve I saw them again with the two women, and about a quarter of an hour after that I saw them going towards their home—I received informa
tion and took them—Cummins was in bed.

JOHN WALLIS (policeman, M 224). On 29th Nov., about a quarter-past twelve o'clock, I was called, and found Bevan lying on the pavement on his face, bleeding very much from a wound on the top of his head—here are his trowsers (produced)—one pocket is torn right off—I took him to the station, and afterwards picked up this canvas bag, with three shillings and two six pences in it.

WILLIAM BEVAN
re-examined. This is my bag, and was in my pocket that evening.

Cummins' Defence. Bevan was not in a fit state to go to his ship, and asked me to see him there; as we went along, we met the two women; be would go with them; I insisted on following, as be bad been in my charge all night; it was most likely after we left him that the women robbed him, and then informed the police.

CUMMINS—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

DONOVAN—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

MORGAN—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

169.
EDWARD COX was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which be pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

170.
GEORGE DAY was indicted
for a like offence.

THOMAS CHARLES HATT . On 30th Oct., the prisoner came to my shop in Kennington-lane for half-a-quartern loaf; it came to 3d.—he put down a shilling; 1 put it into the till—there were only three sixpences there—he came again three or four months afterwards for a half-quartern loaf, and gave me another shilling which I put into the till—no other money had been pat in, and nobody had been to the till—my mother took out both the shillings when the prisoner had left and wrapped them up in paper—next day, about seven o'clock, the prisoner came again and asked for a twopenny loaf—he

laid down a shilling—I put it to my teeth, and said, "This is a bad one"—he took it up, looked at it, and said, "I know where I have taken it"—I gave it him back—I afterwards saw him in East-lane, and gave him in custody.

GEORGE CLARK . I am a bricklayer. On 31st Oct., I was in Mr. Hatt's shop, and followed the prisoner to East-lane—he joined five men, and gave something to one of them who ran away with it—I afterwards saw the pri
soner in custody.
SARAH HATT . I am the wife of Thomas Hatt. On 30th Oct., I found two bad shillings in the till, with three sixpences—I wrapped them in paper and put them at the back of the till.

THOMAS HATT . On 30th Oct., I came home at ten o'clock at night, and locked up the till—next morning I saw two shillings wrapped up in paper at the back of the till—I marked them, and gave them to Butt.

ALFRED AVERY . On 31st Oct., the prisoner came to our house in the Kent-road for some beer, and put down a new Victoria shilling—I put it into the till—there was a half-crown, sixpence, two fourpenny pieces, and two old shillings there.
JAMES WILLIAM AVERY . I am the brother of the last witness. On 31st Oct. I went to the till, took out the Victoria shilling, and gave it to Mottram—there were two old shillings there.
JAMES MOTTRAM (policeman, A 472). I received a shilling from the last witness, marked it, and gave it to Butt.

GEORGE BUTT (policeman), Hatt pointed the prisoner out to me coming out of a public-house—I took him, and told him what it was for—he said he certainly had attempted to pass a bad shilling, but he had bit it in two, and chucked it into the gutter—Hatt gave me two shillings, wrapped in paper, from the back of the till—I received another bad shilling from Mottram. JOHN KEMPSTER. These three coins are bad.

Prisoner's Defence. I have been employed by Mr. Waghorn in India, but am now seeking employment; I overtook two young men at New-Cross, who gave me some drink, and bought some cheese, and asked me to get a half-quartern loaf, and gave me a shilling; I got it, and one of them said it was such beautiful bread he wanted another to take home; he gave me a shilling, and 1 went again and got another; I drank, and left them; next day an engineer at Greenwich gave me a shilling to take me home to my mother; I did not know it was bad, and went to the same shop for a loaf; they said it was bad; I thought it was not, and went to the public-house for half-a-pint of beer; there were three gentlemen kept up with me, but I did not see the six or seven men.
GUILTY , recommended to mercy by the Jury. Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months.

171.
FREDERICK TURTON and
TIMOTHY KELLY were indicted for
a like offence: to which

TURTON pleaded
GUILTY .** Aged 16.—
Confined One Year.

JAMES SAGE . On 8th Nov. I was in the Bell, at Putney. Turton came and called for a pint of beer—Mr. Avis, the landlord, served him—he tendered half-a-crown—Mr. Avis said it was bad, gave it him, and told him to be careful not to give it to anybody else—I followed, and saw him join Kelly about twenty yards off—they went towards the Star and Garter—Turton went in, Kelly remained outside, about ten yards off smoking a long pipe—I went in, and heard Turton call for a pint of beer—he tendered half-a-crown to Miss Lovelook, who said it was bad, and called Mr. Hall, who said, "You are the lad I am looking for," and asked where he got it—he

said of a gentleman who he sold some paper and envelopes to—Hall asked if anybody was with him—he said his brother was outside—Mr. Hall went out, brought Kelly in, and asked them if they had got any bad money—they said, "No"—Turton pulled out some silver and halfpence—when I said I had seen them at the Bell they burst out crying.
EMMA LOVELOCK . I live at the Star and Garter, at Putney. Turton passed a bad half-crown to me—I gave it to Cox.

JONATHAN HALL . I received this half-crown from my daughter-in-law, the last witness—I asked Turton where he got it—he said a gentleman gave it him for some envelopes, and said he had no more bad money—he at first denied having any one with him, and then said his brother was outside—I went out, and found Kelly with a pipe in his mouth, brought him in, and asked him if he had any bad money—he said, "No"—I marked the half-crown—this is it (produced.)

JOHN AVIS. I keep the Bell. Turner came to my house, and asked for some envelopes and paper, and a pint of porter—he gave me half-a-crown—I said it was bad, and gave it him back—he said he took it for a good one—I told him not to attempt to pass any more, or he would get into trouble—I have every reason to believe this half-crown is it; I did not mark it.

EDWARD COX (policeman), I took the prisoners at the Castle, and told them the charge—they said they had not done it—on Turton I found 2s., three sixpences, a 4d.-piece, and 6d. in halfpence, all good—Kelly put his band to his mouth; I heard something in his mouth, which rattled like money on his teeth—I put my hand to his throat, and he swallowed it, with difficulty—I found 6¼d. in copper on him—I received this half-crown from Miss Lovelock (produced.)
HENRY UNDERHILL (policeman). I took Turton, and took this bad half-crown, and 4s., and two sixpences, from his hand.
JOHN KEMPSTER . These half-crowns are all bad.

KELLY—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Two Months.

172.
FRANCIS WILLIAMS was indicted
for embezzlement. MR. BALLANTINE conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE BEECH . I am in the service of the South-Western Railway Company. I am ticket-collector at the Waterloo-station; the prisoner was ticket-collector at the Richmond-station—I had explained to him his duty when he took that appointment—there are instances in which insufficient tickets are taken—persons sometimes take third-class tickets, and ride in second-class carriages—he was in the office nearly a week before he went to Richmond—he was to collect tickets there, and if there were any excess fares he was to receive them, and pay them the next morning—the excess fares were to be entered on a sheet immediately after receiving them, and those sheets would be exhibited at the Richmond-station.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Ought the prisoner to have given you the excess fares? A. He ought, while he was with me—I am at the Waterloo-station—I have found mistakes there, in summer time, when we have an immense number of persons to collect from—if a person received several excess fares, as 1s. 2d., 8d., and 4d., he might enter it as 2s., 2d., if it were a very heavy train, and they were paid at the same time—there is a man of the name of Smith under me; he has not made a mistake of this kind; it was in reference to excess fares—we start special-trains—it ought to be known by the servants on the line that the special-trains are sent—here

are two check-takers at the Richmond-station—the prisoner came in April, 1847—Smith did not make a mistake similar to this; he had taken excess fares, and written his name on the back of the tickets, and not entered it in the book—I never knew that men hare made a mistake in entering excess tares in a lump, instead of entering them separately—I never knew it done at the Waterloo-station.

AMELIA ANN HARVEY . I live in Vine-terrace, York-road, Lambeth. On 25th Aug, I took one ticket for myself, and one for my sister, to go to Putney—I went by the train from the Waterloo-station, at thirty-five minutes past four o'clock—I went on to Richmond, and gave up the tickets to the prisoner—my sister asked him if there was anything to pay, and he said, "Yes, 8d. each"—I gave him a half-crown, and he gave me 1s. 2d., out.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go down to Putney at the instance of Bent, the policeman? A, Yes; I have known him about nine months—I never lived with him, nor did my sister—I live with my mother—I get my living by needlework—I am not in the habit of keeping company with Bent; he sometimes comes backwards and forwards, and buys tobacco of my mother.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Is the house your mother lives in belonging to the Railway? A. Yes; it is perfectly respectable.
ELIZABETH ANN HARVEY . I am sister of the last witness—I live with my mother—I went down with my sister to Richmond—I saw the 1s. 4d. paid to the prisoner.
Cross-examined, Q. Did your sister tell you that the policeman asked her to go down? A. No; my sister paid my fare and her own—I have known Mr. Bent about eight months.

PATRICK MEHAN . I am a reporter. On 2d Sept. I went in a second-class carriage to Richmond—I did not take any ticket—when 1 got to Rich
mond the prisoner was taking tickets there—I paid him 1s. 2d.—I afterwards gave information—when I was going down the officer spoke to me, and asked me to do this.

Cross-examined, Q. Were you accidentally on the platform? A. Yes; I paid my own fare out of my own pocket—I went alone—I think Bent was in the same train; not in the same carriage—I have known him as a police
man for some years—he asked me where I was going, and 1 told him, and he said there were some officers that he suspected—I gave evidence before the Magistrate, and I think I reported the case on that occasion—I was a witness, by accident—I was not invited by the officer to do this; he asked me to do it—I was never in any difficulty of any kind—there was never any charge made against me—I think I was charged at the Mansion-house with knocking a man down—I was never charged with a more grievous offence; certainly not—I was never charged with violating the person of a child; it is abomi
nable that I should be asked such a question; it is false; I know nothing of such a charge; I deny it most indignantly—I do not think I have ever travelled with Bent before; certainly never in company with him; he might be in the same train—I very likely might have taken a glass of spirits with him—I think I had some refreshment at Richmond with him and the Miss Harveys—he is no personal friend of mine; I know him from bis frequently bringing charges to the courts—I have not frequently drank with him; I dare say 1 may have drank with him; I have treated him; I paid for it this time—I have not received anything for this, nor do I expect it.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long have you pursued the profession you now follow? A. Twenty-five or twenty-six years—I do not know that

was bound to report this case; but I gave a paragraph of it at the court at Richmond—there is not the least ground for the charges which have been mentioned—I do not know who could have invented them.
THOMAS BENT (policeman, V 95). I went down with Mr. Mehan.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you known him before? A. Yes, for some years—I think we had some refreshment together after we got to Richmond. I think I had taken refreshment with him once or twice before; I think not oftener—he paid the fare to Richmond, and I paid it afterwards—I had never paid it before—I think this time it was 1s. 2d. down and 1s. 4d. back, because we came from Twickenham—I paid the fare both ways—I think I rode in the same carriage with him down, but not up. I gave the young ladies money to pay their passage—I have known them about eight months I do not keep company with them—I have never walked out with them in an evening—they might have been at places where I have been, but I have not seen them—what I did, I did by order of my superiors.

CHARLES STANLEY . I am a private watchman, in the goods' warehouse of the London and South-Western Railway—I was directed to go down to Richmond on 2d Sept.—I did not take a—ticket when I got to Richmond I paid the prisoner 2s. for myself and a female who was with me—I was not known to the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. What train was this you went by? A. Ten minutes past four; a special train—it was on a Sunday—I know the Miss Harveys—I may have known them six months—I am not in the habit of keeping company with them—I was once at a theatre with them

JAMES GILL HORSFORD . I am a ticket-collector at the Richmond station—the prisoner was associated with me as collector—he and I were the only collectors there for the last eight or nine months—each of us put down in the excess fare-book what we receive—this is the book—on the 25th Aug. here are some returns under the thirty-five minutes past four-o'clock-train—they are not my writing—I believe them to be in the prisoner's writing—here is no return of 1s. 4d. as excess fare by that train—on the 2d Sept. there is no entry by the prisoner of 2s. or 1s. 2d. by the ten minutes past four train—it would be his duty to enter them if he received the money—that it our instructions.

Cross-examined. Q. Is this the excess fare-book? A. Yes, it is the book that I and the prisoner jointly had at the Richmond station to enter the excess fares in—we each enter our own—this "2s. 4d." is in my hand
writing—this "1s. 6d." and "1s. 2d." are not—there are no entries of mine on 2d Sept.—I believe the entries to be the prisoner's writing—I could not swear to his writing.

Q. Suppose you receive from one person 1s. 4d., from another 8d., and from another 4d., might you not put them down in one sum, 2s. 4d.? A. No; we put them down separately—when the line was first opened, they might have been put down together—there has been a case where we have been too late for the clerk, and we have paid the next morning—we put down each separate sum as far as lies in our power—there are no other money-takers but ourselves—we receive on both sides, both from the up nod down trains, and account afterwards to the clerk—there is a good deal of hurry sometimes—we give change out of our own money—we seldom have ten or twelve excess fares; we have two or three—it frequently has occurred that the moment we let out passengers from one train we have to run the other to take them—we sometimes do not know the times of the special trains; we do sometimes—I have made mistakes.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When was the next train down after the thirty, five minutes after four? A. The 5h. 15m., then the 5h. 35m., and then the 7h. 15m.

ALFRED CLOAKE . I am booking-clerk at the Richmond station—it was my duty to receive the excess fares from the collectors—I did so on 25th Aug.—the prisoner did not account to me for 1s. 4d. received by the thirty-five minutes past four train—there is no 1s. 4d. here (producing a book)—he did not on the 2d Sept. account for 2s. by the ten minutes past four train-there is 2s. entered in this book; but I do not know in whose writing it is—that is by the 7h. 30m. train—there is no 2s. to the ten minutes past four train nor 1s. 2d. by that train—it would be the prisoner's duty, if he received these sums, to enter them.

Cross-examined. Q. Does it happen that they cannot always put the fares opposite the trains they come by? A. I believe that is sometimes im
possible—I do not know that it is customary to put them opposite some other trains; but I believe it to be almost impossible sometimes to put them opposite the right train. I can say there have been omissions, and they have said,"We omitted to put this as we had so much;" I believe that it has been often—Sunday is a busy day; and on Saturday evening, if it is fine, many persons go down and sleep there.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Look at the train at thirty-five minutes past four, on 25th Aug., and tell me whether there are any entries of excess fares under that train? A. Yes; there are six entries—probably the prisoner would have time to enter the others—on the 2d Sept. I do not see any entries of excess fares by the ten minutes past four train from London—special trains would not be entered in this book—they would be put down in the next train that would follow at half-past seven—here is "2s." here, but not "1s. 2d." by that train.

CORNELIUS STOVIN . I am general traffic-manager on the London and South-Western Railway—I had been down to the ticket-collectors about a fortnight before 25th Aug.—I had seen the prisoner, and had some conversa
tion with him and the other collector—I did not give them any directions with reference to their keeping these books for the future—I merely made inquiry in what manner they were in the habit of entering the account of their excess fares—they both said they were in the constant habit of making the entries immediately after the departure of the train, and paying the money to the clerk; there was a train which left on Sunday, 2d Sept., and it would be the duty of the collectors to enter the fares received by that im
mediately after the departure of the train, whether it were general or a special train.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you differ in opinion from Mr. Cloake? A. I do not know what his opinion is; I told the prisoner there had been some defal
cation, and he said he was very sorry, but there was no defalcation on his part—I do not know much of keeping the excess fare-books—I have not bad the receipt of these trains—I do not know that it is not the habit to enter special-trains—Mr. Cloake is a clerk; he receives the money—each ticket-collector, before he enters on his duty, serves a sort of apprenticeship at the terminus—I do not think they have any express instructions in writing as to the return of the excess fares, and what they should do with the money, any more than that it is a generally understood thing, that they ought to account for any money that they receive—I do not know that the words "special train" are entered in any excess fare-book.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You say the men are at the terminus till they know their duty? A. Yes; I do not think any special-train would be men
tioned in this Waterloo-book; it would give the hour; but whether the train were special or general, they would have no other duty but to enter it imme
diately after the arrival.

GKOROB BEECH
re-examined. Q. What was the habit of collecting the excess fares? A. It was the duty of the collector to go and write down the time it arrived, and write down "special-train" if it were so; that is always done at our station.
Cross-examined. Q. But the country collectors do not know when special-trains come? A. Not always.
COURT. Q. When it does come, is it their duty to enter the excess fares immediately, and not wait for the next? A. Yes.

MR. PARRY. Q. Suppose two trains arrive, one up, and one down, how is it possible to do it? A. A man may take the excess fares of many, but the tickets would show in most cases which they belong to.
NOT GUILTY .

173.
JOHN WILLIAMS
, unlawfully breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Cory, with intent to steal.

WILLIAM CORY . I live at 11, Commercial-road, Lambeth At half-past seven o'clock in the evening of 28th Oct., I heard my front-door open—I was sitting in my parlour, with the passage-door open—I went into the pas
sage, and saw the prisoner, who had advanced two or three paces into the passage—he asked me if a man named Williams lived there—I did not answer him, but walked up and seized him by the wrist—he had put the door to, but not shut it—I wheeled him round and called the police, and gave him into custody—I distinctly heard the door opened with a Bramah key—the prisoner was searched; the key which opened the door was in his hand, and seven or eight other picklock keys were found on him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you? A. In my par
lour; the door which leads into the passage was wide open—I cannot recol
lect whether I had shut the street-door myself—my wife and servants had gone out to Church, about twenty minutes past six o'clock.

WILLIAM WESTON (policeman, L 65). On 28th Oct. I was called, and took the prisoner—I asked him for the key that opened the door; he gave me this key, which opened it—I found on him seven other keys, two of which are skeleton keys.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he found the door open? A. Yes; it was after that, I asked for the key.

GUILTY .* Aged 28.—
Confined Nine Months.

174.
MARY ANN JACKSON
, stealing 1 breast-pin, value 3l. 10s.; the goods of
William M'Farlane, from his person.

WILLIAM M'FARLANE . On the morning of 26th Oct. I was walking along a part of London that I do not know very well. I saw the prisoner, and asked her the way; she said it was this way; I went with her—I fancied she was an Irishwoman, and got into conversation with her—she said she thought a little breakfast would do me good, and she would be glad to give me a cup of tea; I said I had no money, and was not accustomed to take refreshment from a stranger in that way—I went into a house, which I thought was hers, to get the tea; after I had sat for two or three minutes, and the tea was not forth
coming, the prisoner was gone—I went into another room, and saw an older

woman—I said, "Where is the landlady?"—she said, "I am the landlady"—I said, "I was led to believe that other person was the landlady"—she said, "No; she only comes now and then"—I then missed my pin from my cravat, and told a policeman; this is my pin—I am not aware that her hand touched my person, or I hers—this pin was in my cravat.

Prisoner. I did not steal the pin, or I should not have pawned it in my own name; I found it; I met him in Westminster-road; he said he had been out all night, and asked if he could go home with me; I took him in, and said it was not my own place; we went into the bedroom, and he took off his coat and hat, and laid down, and the landlady came to the door, knocking, for the money. Witness. It was not so; I had changed my dress, and left my purse in my other trowsers; there was nothing said about money—I had been out at a party—that might have been part of the conversation—I had not been in bed—I know I had the pin in my cravat the same morning, and I was in no company from the time I left the party till I got into the prisoner's house.
THOMAS GRAMMAR . The prisoner asked me to purchase this pin.

WILLIAM BROAD (policeman, L 82). I took the prisoner four days after
wards—she said she had never seen the prosecutor, and only came out of Kingston that day.
NOT GUILTY .

175.
MARIAN ALDRED
, stealing 2 5l. Bank-notes; the property of
Alfred Cooper, in the dwelling-house of
Charles Cooper.

ALFRED COOPER . I live at 7, Oxford-terrace, Clapham-road. The pri
soner was living servant with my brother there—on 13th Oct. I lost two 5l.-notes; they were in my left-hand waistcoat pocket when I took the waistcoat off—I spoke to the prisoner about them—she said she had not seen them, that I must have lost them out of doors—I afterwards looked into her work-box, and found two duplicates—I went to the pawnbroker's on 7th Nov.—I traced one of the notes from the Bank, and they paid it to Masterman's.

HENRY WINCH . I live with Mr. Brown, a pawnbroker. I produce this 5l.-note, which I took of the prisoner, who bought a gold chain, on 5th Nov.—the note was quite new and clean—she gave her address, "Dyer, 10, Rod
ney-row, Kent-road"—this is the chain she bought (produced).

ALFRED COOPER
re-examined. The 13th Oct. was a windy, rainy night—the notes were quite clean—it was not possible they could have got out while I was outside—I did not open my coat till I got in—if they had got out they would have been dirty—the roads were very muddy—this note is quite clean.
CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant, L 8.) I took the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I found the note near the gate as I was returning from an errand.
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Four Months.

176.
ALEXANDER WILSON
, stealing 1 handkerchief; value 3s.; and 1 neck-tie, 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Brooks, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Two Months.

177.
JOHN DAVIS
, stealing 1 sack and 4lbs. weight of flour, value 2s.; the goods of
William Waters, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Confined Three Months.

178.
GEORGE BROOME
, stealing 24 cigars, value 45.; the goods of
James Benton; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years. (The sergeant of the regiment to which the prisoner belonged stated that he bore a very bad character, and had been tried by Court-martial.)

179.
WILLIAM GIGGS
, stealing 36 trusses of hay, value 3l.; the goods of
John Mason. MR. MELLER a conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS WELLS . I am in the service of Mr. John Mason, a hay-dealer of Bushy; on 14th Nov. he sent me to London with a load of hay, to sell. I went to Charing Cross—I saw the prisoner there—I had not known him before; he asked if I would sell the hay, and what I wanted for it—I told him three guineas; he said that was too much—I said, "Well, then, 3l., and a shilling for myself?"—he said, "Well, I will have it"—I said, "I hope you are not going to take me far?"—he said, "No, only just over the water"—I Said, "There is another thing; I must not go home without the money, my master gave me orders not to go home without it"—he said, "Do you think I mean to do you out of the money?"—he said he would buy it—he said, "Let us go over and have a glass of gin;" and asked me if I had any halfpence,—I said, "No, only a few, but I have a sixpence"—he said, "You may as well let me have that till the hay is sold, and then I will give it you back again"—I was to have the money as soon as the hay was unloaded—he took me to a butcher's shop at Walworth, where he talked about selling it—ten of the trusses were taken in there, by order of Mr. Williams, the butcher—he bought the hay of the prisoner—the prisoner told me to stop there—no one carried it in—we put the cart up, and put the hay in the loft—he bought a quarter of a load, but there was one truss more put in by mistake, and there was one truss he did not like; it was put down and we put another one up—the prisoner went to get the money, and I was to stop round the corner—the prisoner came back and offered me five shillings—he said, "You had better take that to bind the bargain"—I said, "I cannot take that, I must have it all"—a cowman came along and bought the remainder of the hay of the prisoner, not of me—I do not know what he was to give for it—we went down to his house—I do not know where he lived—I am no scholar—when we got there he helped to take out the remainder of the hay—I asked for the money—the prisoner said he could not pay me—we came along, a little way from the place—there was one man with him; he gave the man a half-sovereign, what change the man gave him I do not know—the prisoner then said I must stop in town all night; he put the horse up, and said he would pay the expense; he said he had to take 13l. on Friday morning and he would pay my money and the expenses—I was forced to stop, for I could not go away without the money—I followed him very closely—he said, "I wish you would go home."

Prisoner. Q. I bought it, at Charing Cross, for 3l.? A. Yes; and a shilling for myself—after we got over Westminster-bridge you left me, perhaps half an hour; you and I together unloaded the first load—you took the money for that—when you sold it, I took some of it off and you took some—I knew you had got the money—you asked me if I would take fifty shillings—you never showed it to me—you said you could not pay me until Friday morning—you gave me five shillings for myself, and you gave me the sixpence that you borrowed of me—I did not get half-a-crown of you, you threw down two half-crowns—I slept at the Swan, and came to your house next morning to breakfast—I had nowhere else to go—I was waiting for my money.
MR. MELLER. Q. On your oath, did you intend to let the hay go without the money? A. No;

JOHN MASON . I am a hay-dealer at Bushy; I sent Wells to town with a load of hay—I told him if he could sell it going along he might, but not to bring me less than 3l. back, if not, to take it to Mr. Kenny's—I never allow
my men to sell it without ready money—I know the prisoner; I would not have trusted him for a single truss, nor half a truss.
Prisoner, Q. You came to town and saw my wife, and did you not say you would wait till the following Wednesday? A. No; 1 said I should go to the Magistrate, and by his advice I should abide.

THOMAS WILLIAMS . I am a butcher, at Walworth. I had seen the pri
soner once before, and bought hay of him—he came to me that Wednesday, brought the hay to the door, and asked me if I would buy half a load, or a quarter of a load—I agreed to buy a quarter for 13s. 6d.; and it was delivered, and one truss over; I paid the prisoner 1s. 6d. for that—I did not under
stand him to say that it was his own hay.
THOMAS LOCKYER (policeman, L 135). I took the prisoner, and told him it was for stealing a load of hay—he said he could only make a debt of it.

The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he intended paying for the hay, but was unable to get sufficient money to do so; that he offered the nan 2l. 10s., which he refused to take, and before he could make up the money he was given in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined One Year.

180.
GEORGE BISHOP
, stealing 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; the goods of
Thomas Ash, and 1 handkerchief, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Robert Halton; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 53.—
Confined Three Days. (DANIEL BISHOP, the prisoner's brother, stated that he was a decided, mad man, and promised to take care of him.)

181.
ROBERT BOWMAN
, stealing 2 half-crowns, 7 shillings, 5 six-pences, 4 pence, 4 halfpence, and 1 farthing; the moneys of
James Muirhead, from the person of
Elizabeth Muirhead; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

182.
MICHAEL WHALE
, stealing 43 pairs of boots and 12 pairs of shoes, value 9l. 11s. 6d.; the property of
Abraham Jacob Lion, and another.

ABRAHAM JACOB LION . I keep a shoe-warehouse, in Crown-street, Fins-bury. In the beginning of July, the prisoner called and gave an order to my brother, who is my partner, to send some boots and shoes to 34, Lisle-street, Kent-road—we said we could not send them unless he paid or lefts deposit—he promised that he would call again in the afternoon, but he did not—in a fortnight afterwards he called again, and gave us a fresh order, and we were to send the goods next day—he left ten shillings deposit—we sent them, and desired the porter not to leave them without the balance of the money—we did not consider the deposit as part payment—we did not like to send the goods at all—we gave the porter directions several times not to leave them without the money; and when he was gone, 1 sent after him to say so.
Prisoner. I left a deposit of ten shillings, and took a receipt of him; he did not send them all, only a part, and part of them were wrong.

Witness. The porter went back the same evening to bring the goods or the money—I went myself at twelve o'clock at night; I saw the prisoner; I wanted the goods back, or the money; he would not do so—I said I would give him the ten shillings back again—I did not have him taken up, because I did not know the law—I saw another case in the newspaper, and then I had him taken on this—I saw no appearance of a shoe-shop, or shoe-business
there—we wanted to hate him taken, but onr lawyer spoke about the ton shillings, and consulted Mr. Wood about it.

JOHN JONES . I took three dozen and a half of short boots, and one dozen and a half of slippers to the prisoner's house, and knocked at the door—I asked a little boy if Mr. Whale lived there—he said, "Yes"—the prisoner opened the parlour door, and said, "Bring them in"—he opened them, and found there were four pairs short, and he found fault with four pain; he said to me, "Take these back, and bring four pairs of others"—I said I could not leave the goods without the money—he said," You can't take these back; take these four pairs back"—he insisted on my going back with them, and said, "Can you come back this evening?"—I said, "I don't think I can"—he said, "Come in the morning by eleven o'clock, I will wait at home for you"—I went to my master and told him—he gave me four pairs of others for what I brought back, and the other four which were short—I went back, and saw the prisoner; he said, "I did not think you would come back to
night"—I said I did not think I could—I said I must have the money or the goods—he said, "I can't give you the Others back, I have taken the trouble to size them and brush them, to send in the morning"—he took those that I brought, and took the invoice from me—he said he could not give me the goods back—I said I could not leave them—he brought me out a chair to sit down—he said, "You can sit there as long as you like: I shan't turn you out"—he said he should not give me the goods back, nor the money, if I called at eleven in the morning be would pay me—I stopped an hour—I asked him for the invoice to take back with me—he said he should not give it me back, and I was obliged to leave the house without anything—I went to my master's, and told him—my father was there; he wanted to know why I stopped so long—I asked my father to go with me—my father, my master and I, all went together—my father knocked at the door—the prisoner's wife came, and said, "Who is there?"—my father said, "Me"—the prisoner came down, and opened the door—we all went in—the goods were lying on the banisters—my master said he wanted the goods or the money—the prisoner said he would not pay to-night, he would call in the morning and pay.
Prisoner. Q. Did not I say you might take the goods back that night if you liked? A. No.

GEORGE HORNSBT. I am a pawnbroker—I have some boots I took in of the prisoner, one pair on the 6th, one pair on 8th, and one pair on 11th Oct. MR. LION re-examined. These are part of what were sent on the occa
sion, and what the prisoner ordered.

CHARLES BERESFORD YOUNG . I am a pawnbroker—the prisoner pawned a pair of boots with me on 2nd Aug., another pair on 28th Aug., two pairs on 29th Oct., and one pair on 8th Nov.—the prosecutor has seen them and identified them.

EDWIN CHAPMAN . I am a pawnbroker—I have a pair of boots, pawned on 4th Aug.; I do not know by who, in the name of Ann May. MR. LION re-examined These are part of the boots the prisoner got. GEORGE QUINNEAR (police-sergeant, P 1). I took the prisoner on 11th Nov. on another charge—I searched his house, and found ninety-five duplicates, and seven on his person—eight, found in his house, relate to those produced by these different pawnbrokers—fifty-six of them related to boots and shoes. Prisoner. Most of them were my own manufacture, and some have been returned on my bands, and with money that I should have got next month I should have redeemed them.
GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined Two Years.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

183.
WILLIAM PAYNE
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; the goods of
John William Wyatt, from his person.

MR. DAWSON conducted the Prosecution. JOHN WILLIAM WYATT. I am a clerk in the Provincial Bank of Ireland, Old Broad-street. On 3rd Nov. I was in the Borough, about half-past five o'clock—I had left the bank, about five minutes past five—I had my pocket-handkerchief then—in High-street, in the Borough, I felt a person take it—I turned round and saw two persons running—I could not identify them—the prisoner is about the size of one of them—they were about a middling height; a person spoke to me—I afterwards saw the prisoner at the police-court—I have not seen my handkerchief since.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. IS not this the first time you have said anything about two persons running away? A. I think not—(Me depo-sition being referred to did, not contain it)—I must have omitted it, 1 did not think much of it.
MR. DAWSON. Q. Where was Arkwright? A. He appeared to me to be looking in one of the shops—the persons were running towards London Bridge, and were about 100 yards behind me.

JAMES ARKWRIGHT . I live in Wilderness-street, Long-lane, and am a currier. On Saturday afternoon, 3rd Nov., I saw Wyatt in the Borough, from a quarter to half-past five—I had seen the prisoner follow two or three gentlemen before—then Wyatt and his friend came past—the prisoner followed them for about a minute—he then took the handkerchief and ran away—I ran about twenty yards after him, but found I could not overtake him—I turned and went to the prosecutor, knowing the prisoner well before. Cross-examined. Q. How many times have you been a witness? A. I have had fourteen or fifteen convictions—if I see persons do wrong I think it is my duty to have them brought up—I do not know that it is better pay than being a currier—I do not know that there is any pay—I have got the same as others—I had 3s. a day in the other Court.
NOT GUILTY .

184.
JOHN GREEN
, stealing 2 trowels, value 4s.; the goods of
Edwin James Embleton.

EDWIN JAMES EMBLETON . I am a plasterer, of Peacock-street; I know these two trowels, they are mine. On 5th Nov. they were safe between one and two o'clock, and when I returned from dinner I missed them.

Cross-examined by MR. WOOLLETT. Q. How do you know this one? A. By wearing the shank off; and I had a letter put on the back—by constant wear it is very nearly worn out, and by my driving the shank up in the handle—I know this other one by having it in constant use.

RICHARD Moss (policeman, P 330). I saw the prisoner at eight o'clock at night, at the corner of Lock's-fields, with a small bag under his arm—I asked him what he had got; he said, "Two trowels"—I asked where he got them; he said it was all right—I said I did not know that—I took him to the light, and he had got six trowels; these are two of them—he said he had bought them of a man who was gone to Australia, he did not know his name, nor where he had lived.

GUILTY .* Aged 41.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

185.
JOHN BUTLER,
ROBERT FINCH,
JOHN MERITY , and
GEORGE DIPPLE
, stealing 216lbs. weight of lard, and other articles, value 6l. 6s.; the goods of
John Ruck, the master of Butler and Finch.—2nd COUNT, charging MERITY and DIPPLE with receiving the same.

MR. PARRY conducted the Prosecution. PATRICK EDWARD DONELEY. I am clerk to Mr. John Ruck, who carries on business as John Ruck and Co., at Topping's Wharf, Tooley-street; he sells grease, lard, and butter; Butler and Finch were in his employ, as porters. In consequence of something we heard, two police
men were requested to watch the premises, on the morning of 9th Dec.; I was also vigilant—on that morning I received a communication from one of the policemen, and I went to Wellington-street; I saw a cart there, which contained two barrels and three firkins—the prisoner Dipple was sitting in the cart—after a short time Merity came up the steps leading from my employer's premises to London-bridge; he got into the cart, and as he got in, Dipple spoke to him; directly he got in, the cart drove on—I saw a cab, and a constable who was with me got on the box of it; that was about fifty yards behind the cart—I observed Dipple point me out to Merity directly he got into the cart, and they drove on across the bridge—I then saw Dipple point out the policeman to Merity, and directly he saw the policeman on the cab he turned back, and drove over the bridge more rapidly than I could follow them—I followed as fast as I could, and the policeman followed in the cab; the cart went down Duke-street, where the front of our premises are—I took a short cut, and arrived at the back of the premises, just as the cart arrived—I saw Merity and Dipple jump out—Merity said to Dipple, "Look sharp!"—they wheeled two barrels out of the cart, and attempted to wheel them into the cellar; I prevented it, by seizing hold of Merity and Dipple, and the barrels remained on the pave
ment—Merity said, "Let me go, it is all right"—I said, "No, certainly not"—I kept hold of him, but was obliged to leave my hold of the othe—the policeman came up; Merity then endeavoured to get me off him—he said, "Let me go"—I said, "I will not"—he swung me round, and came over the cellar—he plunged into the cellar, and endeavoured to pull me in, but he did not—the policeman came up—Dipple had a barrel in his hand—the policeman took him—I went by another way into the cellar, and met Merity as he was rushing up; and he and I had another struggle in the cellar—Butler and Finch were taken immediately afterwards—one of the barrels was full of lard, and the other half full—one of the firkins contained butter, and the other two grease—the two firkins of grease had been paid for, but they were all in Mr. Ruck's possession—the other things were Mr. Ruck's—Merity said to Butler, "You know, Jack, you gave me these things to sell; I was to get a customer for them"—Butler replied, "I know nothing but what you paid for; I gave you a receipt for what you paid"

Cross-examined by MR. PARNBLL. Q. Was not this what Merity said; "You trusted me with these things till 1 could find a customer?" A. Yes; Butler said, "I gave you a receipt for what you paid; "and Butler said, I know nothing about anything else"—I will swear he said that—there was a great deal of conversation—I think I was excited—I have been in Mr. Ruck's employ four years and a half, and Butler was there before me—I generally got there from half-past eight till nine o'clock in the morning—I got there that morning five or ten minutes before eight—I found Butler there—his time for coming was half-past seven—I saw the cart on London-bridge, about two minutes before I got to the premises—it was the business of Mr. Brasher, the warehouseman, to keep the book, in which would appear what is sold—my

employer's son had sold these articles to Merity the day before—Mr. Brasher and my employer's son have authority to sell—I never sell in the warehouse, I sell when travelling—Mr. Ruck himself sells—if they were all out of the way we have no means of selling—suppose Butler were to sell, Mr. Ruck would not take the money when he came—I know that Merity had not been a customer before—the business was John and Cornelius Ruck's; but Cornelius Ruck has left and set up for himself—I do not know that Merity was a customer of the former firm—I do not know that Mr. Knight and Mr. Warren have had goods of the porters, and afterwards settled with Mr. Ruck—I do not believe it.

cross-examined by MR. WOOLLETT. Q. Has not Merity bad dealings with Mr. Ruck? A. I believe he had one dealing—I expect that has been accounted for—supposing Mr. Ruck and the foreman were away, I might sell goods myself—I do not think I should be doing wrong—I am quite certain, if Mr. Ruck knew that one of the porters had sold goods, he would say he had acted improperly—I have no occupation beside being in Mr. Ruck's service—I sold some spirits on one occasion—when I say I sold it, I mean that I became a purchaser at a Custom-house sale, for two or three friends, and they paid me again for what they had, and the same occurrence took place nine months ago—to the best of my recollection it has never taken place at any other time—on the last occasion I purchased eleven gallons of spirits, to the best of my recollection; and on the first occasion I think it was eight gallons—I purchased it for my friends—I permitted Butler to take one quart of it—I will not swear that I did not sell that at a profit.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You say Dipple pointed to a cab on which the policeman was? A. Yes; and Merity turned round and saw him—they then turned in a direction to pass the policeman—Dipple drove the cart in the first instance, but when they returned, Merity drove—the policeman was in plain clothes.

MR. PARRY. Q. Had Butler, or any other porter, authority to sell, from you or your master? A. They had strict orders not to sell—on one occa
sion I myself gave orders to Butler not to sell in the absence of Mr. Ruck. ROBERT COUSINS BRASHER. I am warehouseman to Mr. John Ruck—I never gave Butler or Finch authority to sell goods—they had no authority to my knowledge.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Have you brought your books here? A. No; 1 do not know of any particular sale to Mr. Knight, of Tooley-street—he has bought goods—he has had goods away, without knowing what the price of them was, when he has sent a printed order—I may have supplied him with goods without knowing the price of them—when such printed orders were brought, it would most likely be delivered to me; if I were out, most likely to Mr. Ruck—there are three or four Mr. Rucks—they are not in partnership—Mr. John Ruck, senior, is the only one—a printed order might be handed to Butler, he would not execute it—I suppose there are thirteen or fourteen persons in the establishment to whom the order might be brought—there are two books, in which an account would be kept of what was sent out, one for the week and one for the fortnight—I went at eight o'clock in the morning—the cart was not there when 1 got there—the grease would be entered in the book, which is kept in my desk at night, and on the desk in the day.

Cross-examined by MR. WOOLLETT. Q. What are your wages? A. 100l. a year—I do not know what Butler's wages are—I am not certain that no
body

else has sold goods while I and Mr. Ruck have been away—others have sold goods besides me—I should not think it very irregular if I were to come to the warehouse, and were told a purchase had been made, and the money received—it would be more irregular for Butler to sell than any one else, because he is not authorized to sell—it is not the custom for persons not authorized, to sell.
MR. PARRY. Q. You have authority to execute orders? A. Yes; and Mr. William Denny Ruck has, and he does sell—Butler does not sell, in the exercise of his duty.

WILLIAM DENNT RUCK . I am in the employ of Mr. John Ruck—I sold to the prisoner Merity two firkins of grease on 7th Nov., I think at 35s. per cwt.—I should think they weighed about f cwt., and would be worth about 30s.—I did not sell him any butter or lard—the firkins and barrels that are here are my father's property—we missed one of these tubs, No. 48, from the warehouse, which had not been sold—the value of the lard and butter is about 6l. or 7l., and the grease bought is about 80s.—I never gave authority to Butler or Finch to sell—no one bad authority to sell in the warehouse and give credit but my father, myself, and my brother.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Had you given Butler orders not to sell? A. I did not think it necessary—I did not think a porter would undertake to sell—I have never ordered any of them not to sell—I missed this tub on the morning it was lost—it was there that morning—I missed two casks of grease which had been standing there the night before, and which I had sold to Merity—I have been in the business fourteen years—Butler has not been there so long—I cannot recollect how long he has been there—I am twenty-nine years old—I began in the business before I was fourteen.

Cross-examined by MR. WOOLLETT. Q. Do you know of any other purchase made by Merity? A. He had previously purchased refuse stuff—I do not think he ever purchased as much as 10l. worth—I cannot recollect his purchasing more than once of the old firm, and that was refuse.

MR. PARRY. Q. You missed this, No. 48, which was found in the cart? A. Yes; I had not sold it, nor given authority to Butler or Finch to sell it JOHN RUCK. I carry on this business—Butler and Finch were in my ser
vice—Butler had 22s. a week, and Finch had 18s.—they had never sold goods without my sanction—I do not know Merity and Dipple.
Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Would it be the practice that those who sold, would enter in the warehouse book? A. Yes; decidedly—they ought to be entered.

GEORGE WILD (policeman, M 94). On 9th Oct., I went to a public-house, from the back parlour of which I could observe Mr. Ruck's premises—I was in company with Ayliffe—we got there about seven o'clock in the morning, on 9th Nov.—there is a door at the back of the premises, and a step or two, and the cellar-flap is by the side of the steps where the crane is—about twenty minutes before eight I saw the horse and cart driven up by Dipple—he drove near the warehouse door of Mr. Ruck's premises—he waited a short time, and Finch came out and began sweeping—he went into the warehouse again, and then I saw him lifting a firkin, and Dipple put it into the cart—I afterwards saw Finch lifting another firkin, and Dipple put it into the cart—I then saw a third firkin lifted, and they put it into the cart—I then saw Finch pull the chain to let it down into the cellar through the flap, and some one in the cellar fixed it to the barrel of lard—I saw a man, who I

believe was the prisoner Butler, as it was drawn up, push it so as to guide it on the pavement—that barrel came up, and was put into the cart by Dipple and Finch—I then saw a tub standing on the pavement with straw in it—it was put into the cart by Dipple and Finch, and the cart was driven up Duke-street—Dipple stopped opposite the steps, and Merity joined him and got into the cart—I had seen Merity go into the warehouse before anything was put into the cart—the cart drove over the bridge opposite the Adelaide Hotel—at that time Dipple was driving—I took a cab and got on the box—I then saw the cart stop, and turn round, and they drove back as hard as they could past me—I turned, and followed them to Tooley-street, where the horse and cart stopped—I jumped off, and saw Merity and Dipple pulling out the tubs, and rolling them on the cellar-flap—I took Dipple and gave him to my bro
ther officer—I then went into the cellar, and took Merity—Butler was stand
ing close by, and Merity said to him, "Jack you know you trusted me with these things to see if I could get a customer"—Butler said, "I gave you a bill, that is all I know"—this is the bill—it is for two casks of grease, 1l. 8s. 9d.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Who is Dipple's master? Mr. Fletcher—he is here—the horse and cart belong to him—Merity hired the horse and cart, and Mr. Fletcher sent Dipple in charge of it with Merity—when I spoke to Dipple, I found that he was apparently hard of hearing—I have heard from Mr. Fletcher that he was an honest man—when I took him he was very quiet—he did not resist at all—it was from what he said that I went to Mr. Fletcher.

ALFRED AYLETT (policeman, M 51). I was with Wild on 9th Nov.—I have heard what he has said—I saw the casks pulled up by these parties—I saw a person, who I believe was Merity, go into the warehouse—I then went to Mr. Donnolly, who was at a coffee-house close by, and then I went over London-bridge—I saw the cart with Merity and Dipple in it—it turned, and I turned and went after it—I believe Merity was driving as it returned, but I would not speak positively to that—I searched Butler, and found on him 3l. 0s. 81l. 2d.—I found a savings bank book at his lodging. (Butler, Finch, and Merity received good characters).

BUTLER—
GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Transported for Seven Years.
MERITY—
GUILTY .—
Confined Eighteen Months.

FINCH and DIPPLE—
NOT GUILTY .

186.
JAMES DICK
, unlawfully obtaining 1l. 2lb. weight of mutton, 1 kidney, and 1 quartern of rum, value (hi.; the goods of
Andrew Gardner : also
obtaining other goods of
Edward Jones, by false pretences: to both which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Six Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 17TH, 1849.
